screening_results.reason: The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=18, ages ~40), performing an ecologically valid joint-action social task (leading vs following) relevant to social processing (perception/understanding of others, social cognition/communication). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Leading>Rest, Following>Rest, Leading>Following) with random-effects analyses and cluster-corrected voxelwise results; Talairach coordinates and figures/tables of activations are reported. Results are clearly from the healthy control sample and generalize to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and does not fall under exclusion criteria. Although some exploratory regressions used a lenient threshold and authors note limitations (small N, potential gender confound), primary whole-brain task-evoked maps are reported. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although this is an fMRI study of social impression formation in healthy adult participants (N=60, mean age 23.8), the manuscript reports multivariate behavioral PLS analyses and brain–behavior correlation (BSR) maps rather than group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (e.g., main-effect or within-group voxelwise contrasts). The paper references prior/unpublished univariate analyses of the same dataset but does not present an unmasked, group-level voxelwise activation map for the healthy sample within this manuscript. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group, this study fails that criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults (n=16, ages 22–34). Participants watched a 20-min movie and social interactions were coded; analyses used a GLM with group-level, whole-brain second-level F-tests and post hoc t-tests. Results include voxelwise, univariate whole-brain statistical maps (voxelwise FWE p<0.05 with clusterwise correction) and reported peak coordinates/tables, clearly from the healthy adult group. The task probes perception and interpretation of others’ social interactions (social cognition/communication). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only). Therefore meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing using a task contrasting social vs nonsocial positive and negative scenes (approach–avoidance), meeting the review’s construct (affiliation/social perception). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (final N=76, males, mean age ~21) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level univariate task contrasts and second-level analyses; although many a priori ROI/SVC analyses are reported, the Methods state and Results reference additional whole-brain exploratory analyses (thresholds and reporting of clusters), indicating availability of whole-brain task-evoked group maps (reported in main text/supplement). Therefore it meets the requirement for whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (mind perception/gaze-cueing) in healthy adult participants (n=22, mean age 24.4). The authors report whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (parametric regressors for mind ratings and gaze-cueing effects) with cluster-based correction and present statistically thresholded activation maps and tables (e.g., vmPFC, TPJ, fusiform). All inclusion criteria are satisfied (social-related fMRI task; healthy adults within 17–65; group-level whole-brain univariate results). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (empathic accuracy/understanding of others) in healthy adults (final N=34, ages 20–30). The task is a social-related, naturalistic Empathic Accuracy Task. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (emotional > neutral contrasts, parametric modulators, time-series correlations) using SPM12 and nonparametric permutation testing with TFCE FWE correction; results are presented as whole-brain clusters/tables and figures. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and healthy-group results are reported separately. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (ages 18–28) and reports voxelwise activation coordinates, the authors explicitly restricted their voxelwise search regions to predefined ROIs (amygdala, insula, IFG, ACC, thalamus, caudate, mOFC) rather than reporting an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map. The inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults. Because all reported statistical inferences were ROI-restricted (no whole-brain results reported), the study fails the whole-brain evidence requirement and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study on social communication: participants classified speakers’ communicative intentions from prosody (social communicative processing). Sample: 22 healthy adult native German participants (mean age 27.4), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS > CLEAR) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction; activations are described in the text and figures. Although PPI connectivity analyses are also reported, whole-brain task activation maps from the healthy adult group are present and clearly generalized to the healthy population. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not between-group-only, not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social decision-making paradigm in which participants allocate money to another person under free vs controlled conditions (a social control-aversion task). Sample: 51 healthy adult participants (mean age 22, within 17–65), with exclusions noted and analyses reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (controlled > free) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak coordinates, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Although the study also includes connectivity (PPI) analyses, it additionally provides univariate, group-level whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met: social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked results reported.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=25 in Study 1; ages 19–24; Study 2 behavioral n=33 also healthy). The task investigates social-related processing (emotion perception/social communication via facial expressions and vocal prosody). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (3×3 repeated-measures ANOVA and contrasts; PFWE-corrected results, cluster extents, and tables of activated regions/coordinates are provided) and ROI analyses. Results for the healthy adult group are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor patient-only samples. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=14 analyzed; ages 23–50). The task manipulates socialness (social vs. non-social images) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (social > nonsocial contrast) with voxelwise thresholds and FDR-corrected cluster inference; coordinates/clusters and conjunction maps are described. Although ROI analyses are also performed, whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy adult group are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI, only connectivity, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI task study of social interaction perception in healthy adult participants (ages 18–34 and 18–30 across experiments). It reports group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., social interaction > independent actions) with FDR-corrected results and surface-based group analyses, clearly from the healthy/control sample. The task probes perception/understanding of others (social interactions), not solely ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=37 male adults, mean age 22.9, within 17–65). The task is explicitly social-related (self-, friend-, celebrity- judgments) addressing Perception/Understanding of Self and Others. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (self vs. celebrity; friend vs. celebrity) with corrected thresholds (p<.05 FDR; voxelwise p<.001) and provides peak coordinates and cluster sizes, satisfying the whole-brain univariate result requirement. Analyses for task-evoked activity and gPPI connectivity are reported for the healthy sample and the whole-brain activation maps are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not clinical-only, and participants are within age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI activation for social cognition (TOM vs Random) in a large sample of healthy adults (Human Connectome Project, n=787; ages 22–>35). The paper provides group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (Cohen's d and level-3 z maps) and describes cerebellar and whole-brain activation clusters for the social contrast. Healthy-control results are reported clearly and are generalizable to the healthy adult population. Although resting-state and seed-based analyses are also included, the paper contains the required task activation whole-brain maps (not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor between-group-only contrasts). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria for the review.

The study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (ages 21–46) who viewed erotic pictures and videos depicting individuals and same-sex couples, engaging perception of others/social stimuli relevant to social processing constructs (Perception/Understanding of Others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (one-sample within-group contrasts, FWE-corrected cluster maps) for each healthy orientation group, not limited to ROI analyses. Whole-brain results are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, or age outside range) are violated. Therefore it meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

The study reports an fMRI task of social interaction (joint action, leading/following, haptic contact) in healthy adult participants (N=18, mean age 40.4). It presents group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., partnered vs non-partnered; improvisation contrasts) with statistical maps and Talairach coordinates, and corrections (FDR) reported. The task probes social-cognitive constructs (perception/understanding of others, mentalizing, social reward), satisfying the review’s content domain. It is empirical, not ROI- or connectivity-only, and the healthy adult group results are reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=36, ages ~20–25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task effects and parametric contrasts (cooperativity vs affectivity) with cluster-corrected statistical maps and tables of coordinates. Although DCM connectivity analyses are included, the study also provides the required healthy-group whole-brain task activation results (figures/tables) generalizable to healthy adults. Sample age is within 17–65 and results for healthy participants are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state only, and not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social/communicative paradigm (collaborative referential communication vs individual/arbitrary learning), directly addressing social communication and mentalizing. Sample: healthy adult participants (directors and matchers; age range 18–33), meeting the 17–65 criterion. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Collaborative > Individual, Collaborative > Arbitrary, Individual > Arbitrary) with cluster-corrected results presented in tables and figures and described in the text; these are generalizable healthy-group task effects. Although an ROI hippocampal analysis is also reported, whole-brain analyses are primary and satisfy inclusion. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, healthy adults reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=59 across three unique participant samples) performing social-related tasks (person knowledge, famous faces/names, socially relevant concept words). Group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts are reported (e.g., social > non-social semantics) with thresholding and peak MNI coordinates and whole-brain maps described in the text and tables. The sample is healthy adults and results for the healthy groups are reported separately. The study is empirical and not ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity/resting-state or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (N=20; ages 23–38) using a social decision-making paradigm (modified prisoner's dilemma) probing Theory-of-Mind/social cognition. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise results (conjunction of task>control and contrasts such as COMP>COOP) with cluster correction and tables of MNI coordinates. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study also includes connectivity analyses, but crucially it includes unmasked whole-brain task activation maps, not ROI-only or resting-state-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adults and examines social/attachment processing, all reported neuroimaging results are seed-based resting‑state functional connectivity (post‑narrative carry‑over effects) rather than group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) activation maps. The paper does not present an unmasked whole-brain task activation map for the healthy group (only FC contrasts and seed-based connectivity results). Per the review’s inclusion criteria, studies must report at least one whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise result for the healthy/control group; therefore this study must be excluded.

Although the study is an fMRI investigation of social evaluation in a healthy adult sample (ages within 17–65) and uses an appropriate social task, the reported neuroimaging results are limited to small-volume–corrected ROI analyses in the ventral ACC. The paper describes group-level modeling and ROI-based SVC (bilateral vACC) and reports only vACC clusters from that ROI. I could not find any unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation maps or whole-brain voxelwise results reported for the healthy group. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map generalizable to healthy adults, and the exclusion criteria disqualify studies that report only ROI analyses with no whole-brain results, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence requirement and should be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social perception (body motion, social involvement) in healthy adults (N=16, mean age 22.8). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task contrasts (main effects and interactions of stimulus type and movement direction) and provides stereotaxic coordinates of BOLD peaks and statistical details. Although targeted masks for the Mirror Neuron and Mentalizing systems were used for searching and inference, whole-brain contrasts were obtained at second level and results are reported as coordinate tables/peaks, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation maps in a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample) apply. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=30, females aged 19–39) to probe social cognition (kinship/moral dilemma) via an ecologically valid movie and a separate moral-dilemma decision task. It reports voxelwise, whole-brain analyses: (1) inter-subject correlation (ISC) results across the whole brain with FDR correction and cluster reporting, and (2) a group-level GLM contrast (decision vs. no-decision) with whole-brain cluster-corrected results (FDR/TFCE, permutation testing) and tables/figures of activations (VMPFC, ACC, DLPFC, etc.). This fulfills inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI during social-related processing, healthy adult sample, and reported group-level whole-brain univariate task activation maps. Not excluded by any criterion (not ROI-only, not resting-state only, no restricted age group). Thus include.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=14; ages 20–32). The study uses task-based fMRI with social-interaction stimuli and reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate contrasts (e.g., interaction > independent; animate > physical), including peak MNI coordinates and statistical maps/figures. Although ROI analyses are also performed, whole-brain task-evoked univariate results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only; not resting-state or connectivity-only; participants are within 17–65). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=27, males aged 20–32) performing social/affiliation-related tasks (an Implicit Association Test with monogamy vs. adultery stimuli and a go/no-go task with attractive female faces). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results for the IAT (incongruent vs. congruent contrasts) with cluster-level FWE correction and tables of activated regions, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the go/no-go analysis focused on a right VLPFC anatomical constraint/ROI, the IAT provides an unmasked whole-brain activation map from the healthy control group. All inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, and group-level whole-brain activations) are met; no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult men (ages 22–50) using task-based visual stimuli that probe social/affiliative processing (romantic images; also sexual and neutral). The authors report whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (whole-head FLAME random-effects, cluster correction) and present group-level contrasts and tables/figures for sexual>neutral (combined participants) and romantic>neutral (within groups and between monogamous vs non-monogamous). Results are reported as voxelwise whole-brain activations (thresholded maps, coordinate tables and figures), meeting the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task map. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and the paper is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

While the study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants and examines social cognition (theory of mind), it reports primarily ROI-based MVPA and individually-defined localizer contrasts (first-level Belief > Photo) rather than presenting a group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation map for the healthy sample. The methods describe defining ROIs from first-level contrasts and report multivariate classification results; I could not find a clear group-level, voxelwise task-evoked statistical map (main effect or within-group contrast) reported in the main text or described as coming from the healthy/control group. Because the review requires at least one group-level whole-brain univariate task map, the study does not meet that inclusion criterion.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (implicit/explicit theory of mind) in healthy adults (final N=22, mean age 24.4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM results from an explicit general-belief localizer (false-belief vs false-photograph) thresholded at q(FDR)<0.05 and provides peak Talairach coordinates and figures. Although ROI analyses were used for the implicit task, the study includes univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts from the healthy/control group and reports coordinates, meeting the meta-analysis whole-brain evidence criterion. Age range and participant health criteria are satisfied and this is original empirical fMRI data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=34 males, ages 19–31 and 22–29), well within the 17–65 range. The task probes social processing (vicarious embarrassment/fremdscham and schadenfreude) — directly relevant to social-affective/Perception and Understanding of Others constructs. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (SIT>NEUT) with FWE-corrected results and tables of activations (Table 1), and describes within-group parametric modulators and second-level random-effects GLMs. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly reported. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 18–27) using a social-cognition task (mental simulation of personally familiar people), the paper reports multivariate analyses (MVPA/RSA and searchlight pattern-similarity maps) rather than group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (e.g., task>baseline or within-group contrasts). The results focus on pattern similarity and feature-selected RSA and do not present an unmasked, group-level voxelwise activation map for the healthy/control group. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one univariate whole-brain task activation map, this study must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=19 for imaging analyses; ages 18–30) using a social task (modified Trust Game) probing reciprocity, a social cognitive construct. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Gave $1.5X vs Gave $0; Gave $1.5X After Receiving, etc.) with cluster results and MNI coordinates in Table 3 and corresponding figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the paper also includes ICA and other analyses, it clearly provides univariate voxelwise task activation maps for the healthy control group. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range, and results are reported for the healthy group separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, non-empirical, out-of-range sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. The neuroimaging cohort included healthy participants aged 18–53 (n=62 after exclusions), within the 17–65 range. The authors conducted whole-brain, group-level univariate GLM analyses (random-effects), reported voxelwise results (thresholded p<.001, permutation correction), and described specific whole-brain activations (e.g., dACC, bilateral dlPFC, parietal cortex, insula). Statistical maps are available on NeuroVault. The task explicitly probes social influence/understanding of others in a decision-making paradigm. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI, only connectivity, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=41, ages 18–24). The task involves social-related processing (decisions to share/select news, engaging social cognition, self-related processing, and valuation). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (select > content, share > content, share > select) with voxelwise results (tables of peak coordinates, FWE-corrected p<.05, k>20) and whole-brain figures. Results for the healthy/control group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study also provides ROI and whole-brain analyses and supplementary materials. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, includes appropriate age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an original fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=38, ages 19–29) using a social-related task (pseudo-interactive joke task assessing action-outcome social contingency). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., SELF vs OTHER; Group vs No Laughter; action-outcome interaction) with voxelwise statistics and FWE-corrected cluster results presented in tables/figures, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, the study also provides univariate activation maps for the healthy control group rather than only ROI or connectivity results. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range, and results are reported for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, outside age range, non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI of social processing (imitate/observe emotional faces — social perception/affiliation/communication). (2) Sample comprises healthy adults (initial N=28, final N=20 after preprocessing; ages 18–55 within 17–65 range) with group-level analyses reported. (3) Provides whole-brain, voxelwise results: authors ran a GLM in SPM8 (reported as showing similar whole-brain activation patterns; Supplementary Figure 1) and present whole-brain voxel maps from the PLS analysis (voxelwise bootstrap ratio maps). Not ROI-only or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria violated. Therefore include as an fMRI whole-brain study of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI task study of mentalising/theory-of-mind (a social cognition construct: Perception and Understanding of Others) in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: N=39, ages 18–60; Experiment 2/fMRI: N=17, mean age 22). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM2), including contrasts (mentalising > factual; parametric modulation of intentionality) with whole-brain corrected results and coordinate tables/figures. Analyses are clearly reported for the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

This paper reports task-based functional MRI studies of social/person-related cognition (person knowledge retrieval), meeting the review’s content requirement. Participants were healthy adults in the target age range (study 1: n=24, Mage≈23.2; study 2: n=26, Mage≈20.4). The manuscript presents group-level univariate, whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., all-memory > baseline, status memory > baseline, trait memory > baseline) with voxelwise FWE-corrected maps and coordinates (Figures S3, Table S6), satisfying the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion. The study also includes MVPA, PPI, and DCM analyses, but these are supplementary to and do not replace the presence of univariate whole-brain task activation maps. No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only; healthy-group whole-brain results are reported). Therefore the study should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult samples (study 1 N=41, study 2 N=39; ages 18–24). Tasks probe social-related processes (self-related processing, mentalizing/social cognition) during exposure to news items. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (whole-brain searches, maps, and tables thresholded and corrected; SI describes whole-brain results and thresholds), not solely ROI or connectivity analyses. Healthy-group effects are presented and generalizable to adults. Therefore it satisfies: (1) functional MRI during social-related tasks, (2) healthy adult sample, and (3) reported whole-brain group-level activation maps/tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, clinical-only) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (face perception/emotional valence and attention) in healthy adult participants (final N=25, ages 21–33). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses: a random-effects faces>objects contrast from the localizer (group t-map, k>9, p<.001) used to define face-responsive ROIs, and whole-brain searchlight results (SnPM corrected). Group-level task-evoked statistical maps are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. The study therefore meets the inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and reported whole-brain group-level task activation), and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (attribution of emotions/perception and understanding of others) using task-based functional MRI. Sample comprises healthy adult participants (final N=16–17; ages 21–46). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Emotion > Expression conjunction across targets; Face > Scramble), with cluster-level FWE correction and whole-brain maps/tables described in the text and figures. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity, and results are reported for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria apply. Thus all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy for pain/perception and understanding of others) conducted in healthy adult males (age 18–40). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked analyses (e.g., STRESS>CONTROL contrasts and whole-brain FWE-corrected results showing activation in AI, aMCC, somatosensory cortex, etc.). Although ROI analyses are used, whole-brain univariate results are explicitly reported and corrected, and the participant groups are healthy adults with results generalizable at the group level. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated (not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results, and participants are within the 17–65 age range). Therefore the study should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=38, ages 18–30) that used a social cognition task (mental state/valence judgments of naturalistic social interactions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (full-factorial ANOVA and contrasts such as Social > Non-social) with whole-brain FWE-corrected results and tables of coordinates/clusters (Table 1 and figures). Results are reported for the healthy sample (no reliance solely on ROIs or connectivity analyses). All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing, empathy, prosocial behavior) in healthy adults. Sample: 32 healthy right-handed female adults (mean age 22.7), within the 17–65 range, with group results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise analyses (SPM12) including second-level paired t-tests and a 3×2 within-subjects ANOVA, with cluster-level correction and tables/coordinates of activation (e.g., Mentalizing > baseline; Dissimilar > Similar; Painful > Non-Painful). Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social related processing in healthy adults.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing (face encoding/recognition) in healthy adults, the reported neuroimaging results are limited to region-of-interest (amygdala) analyses (extracted parameter estimates) rather than univariate, voxelwise whole-brain group activation maps or coordinate tables. The paper does not present a whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy adult group that is generalizable to the healthy population. In addition, the sample includes older adults >65 and the analyses are reported on the combined sample rather than as a separate healthy adult (17–65) group. Therefore the study fails the requirement for reporting whole-brain healthy-group task activation and does not provide separable within-range adult-group whole-brain results, so it must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (effects of social competition/social comparison) in healthy adult participants (N=20 females, ages 18–35). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Competition > No Competition; performance-related parametric modulators) with voxel coordinates, cluster sizes, and cluster-level correction; results are presented in tables and figures (Table 1, Figures 3–5). The healthy-control group results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or resting-state only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (Face Matching Task with fearful and neutral faces — perception/understanding of others). The sample comprises healthy adults (n=10, mean age 25), within the 17–65 range. The paper includes group-level, univariate whole-brain GLM analyses (first-level contrasts and second-level one-sample t-tests for contrasts such as fear>neutral and neutral+fear>control) with reported thresholding and results presented (Table S2 and Figures S1–S3), satisfying the requirement for a whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from the healthy group. Although the paper also presents ICA (connectivity) analyses, this does not conflict with inclusion since univariate whole-brain results are provided. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

Meets all inclusion criteria: study used task-based fMRI probing social cognition (mentalizing about friends and kin) in healthy adult participants (n=25 females, mean age 23). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (friend > kin) and linear parametric whole-brain analyses across social network layers, with cluster-thresholded activation maps and tables of MNI coordinates. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly reported. Although the sample is female-only (limits generalizability), it still represents healthy adults (17–65) and thus qualifies for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study of prosocial (social) learning in healthy adults (n=31 males, age 19–32). The task explicitly manipulated beneficiary (self, other, no one), meeting the social-related task requirement. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked univariate results (whole-brain and ROI analyses) with tables of coordinates and SPM results (e.g., Tables S1–S4, Figures 2–3, Fig. S3) and reports FWE-corrected voxelwise findings, satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and are healthy; results for this healthy group are reported separately. The study is empirical and reports original fMRI data. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-age sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of emotion regulation in response to angry faces (a social stimulus). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=60; age range 18–57), with healthy-group results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Observe-angry > Observe-neutral, Observe-angry > Increase+Decrease) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster statistics and figures, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although resting-state connectivity is also reported, the study includes univariate task-evoked whole-brain results rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only; healthy adults within age range; whole-brain task maps reported). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI experiment of social processing (Prisoner’s Dilemma cooperation) in healthy adult participants (final N=18, mean age 21). The task is clearly social (perception/understanding of others, affiliation/cooperation). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (contrasts such as CC vs. other outcomes; context × cooperation interactions) with cluster-level FWE correction and MNI coordinates reported. Although ROI analyses are included, whole-brain results are also provided and clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy sample are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (cooperation/competition; self- and other-related ability judgments), involving healthy adults (final N=24, ages 19–31). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task analyses (GLMs) identifying regions such as pgACC and area 9 linked to self- and other-performance signals; these are described as whole-brain findings and are not limited to ROI-only results (ROIs used subsequently but after whole-brain identification). The task and contrasts assess perception/understanding of self and others, meeting the review’s construct scope. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, healthy adult sample within range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of attachment (a social-related construct) using task-based BOLD imaging in healthy adults (N=25, ages 19–26). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (attachment vs. neutral; dyadic/monadic interactions) with MNI coordinates and cluster-level corrected statistics, clearly from the healthy/control group. Results are generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to a narrow subgroup. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and meets the sample age criterion. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (pilot N=10, main N=15; all aged ≥18) using social-related tasks (sociality manipulation, Prisoner’s Dilemma, Ultimatum/Welfare games — constructs involving perception/understanding of others, affiliation/social interaction, prosocial behavior). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses using FSL (Pilot) and SPM12 (Main), with cluster/FWE-corrected thresholds and coordinates/tables of activations (e.g., BA8/9, BA11, vmPFC, PCC) and descriptions of contrasts (High vs Low sociality, PD vs UG). Thus it provides whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps/results generalizable to healthy adults. It does not fall under exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state/only connectivity, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore include.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (N=110, age 19–31) using a social cognition paradigm (self-reference vs other-reference). Group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM results are presented (second-level analyses; FWE-corrected whole-brain inference) including contrasts of interest (social > baseline, self > other, other > self) and accompanying tables/figures. Although the paper also includes DCM effective-connectivity analyses, it clearly reports whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy sample rather than ROI-only or resting-state results. All inclusion criteria are therefore satisfied and no exclusion criteria are met.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI task probes social perception/understanding of others (observing actors grasping objects in emotional contexts). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=20, mean age 27). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task analyses (GLM results with whole-brain and ROI-corrected FWE results, cluster- and voxel-level activations reported and discussed) clearly from the healthy participant group. It is empirical original fMRI research; connectivity analyses (PPI/DCM) are supplementary and do not preclude inclusion. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, clinical-only, or non-empirical) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (N=34, mean age 22.2) who performed a social-related task (naturalistic movie viewing emphasizing social interactions). The paper reports group-level task-evoked analyses including whole-brain voxelwise reverse-correlation results (χ2 goodness-of-fit maps and corrected statistical parametric maps visualized in Figure 3) and intersubject correlation statistics, all derived from the healthy adult sample. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses; whole-brain, group-level univariate results are clearly described and corrected for multiple comparisons. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and the healthy group results are reported directly. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=40, mean age 27.8, right-handed, no psychiatric/neurological history) using a social task (modified Cyberball combining social exclusion and performance evaluation). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (random-effects GLM), voxelwise contrasts (e.g., EX > IN, PG EX > FG EX) with FWE correction and tables of MNI coordinates, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and presents healthy-group results generalizable to adults aged 17–65. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although the study tests social tasks (theory-of-mind and social attribution) in healthy adult samples (ages within 17–65), it does not report a group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation map for the healthy group. The analyses use a TPJ-focused (ROI) localized ICA decomposition and report task-related IC maps within the TPJ and seed-to-voxel connectivity maps. These are ROI-limited ICA results and connectivity maps rather than whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked univariate contrasts (e.g., belief>photo) generalizable as a healthy-group activation map. Therefore it fails the “whole-brain evidence” inclusion criterion and meets the exclusion criterion for ROI/ICA-only reporting.

This is an fMRI study of social decision-making (Ultimatum Game) in healthy adult participants (MT group n=27, CT group n=24; ages ~31, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain random-effects analyses (e.g., conjunction analyses, interaction contrasts, cluster- and voxel-wise statistics, MNI coordinates, FDR-corrected results, and supplementary activation tables/figures), clearly attributed to the healthy/control cohorts. Although ROI and PPI connectivity analyses are also reported, these are accompanied by whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) in healthy adults (n=19, ages 20–53). The task (REMICS) manipulates social vs. physical scenarios and contextual adjustment, and group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts are reported throughout (tables of peak coordinates and cluster-level inference, voxelwise thresholds and corrected cluster sizes). Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and healthy-group effects are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of impression updating (social cognition — perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (N=21; ages 18–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (e.g., L2>F3) with voxel-wise thresholds and cluster correction (AlphaSim), and provides tables of peak coordinates and whole-brain results. It is not ROI-only, nor is it limited to connectivity or between-group contrasts; healthy-group whole-brain activation maps/contrasts are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (final N=18, mean age 23.7 within 17–65). The task is explicitly social (inferring others’ emotions from visual/verbal cues with feedback). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses of task-evoked signals (value and prediction-error regressors) with tables of coordinates and conjunction/contrast maps, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are presented for the healthy/control sample (no clinical subgroup confound). Analyses are task-based, not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state approaches. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluation), which maps to ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’. Participants are healthy adults (final N=31; ages 19–24). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and a whole-brain multiple regression (e.g., SC vs SA, OA vs OC, SA vs Fixation) with tables of MNI coordinates and statistical thresholds (voxel-wise p<0.001, cluster-level FWE p<0.05). Although PPI connectivity is also reported, whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult sample within 17–65). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (cooperation vs. competition) in healthy adults (final N=18, ages 21–38). The task is social and theory-of-mind related. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., coop_active > coop_passive; comp_active > comp_passive) with cluster-level correction and tables of peak coordinates (Table 1 and Supplementary Tables), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for the healthy control group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, participants are within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=178, mean age 40.9, within 17–65). It uses a task-based social paradigm (EmpaToM) manipulating empathy and Theory of Mind, with participants performing video-based social tasks during fMRI. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (emotional vs neutral videos; ToM vs non-ToM questions/videos) analyzed with random-effects one-sample t-tests and presents activation peaks and MNI coordinates and figures. Although connectivity/DCM and resting-state analyses are also reported, they do not replace the clear whole-brain task-evoked maps required by the inclusion criteria. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult sample (N=33; ages 20–34) probing social processes (empathy, perspective taking, attention) during a charitable-donation paradigm and complementary social/attention tasks. The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: univariate GLMs and at least one significant group-level whole-brain voxelwise contrast (low > high donations; visual cortex cluster, p < 0.05 FWE) and multiple group-level random-effects searchlight results. Results for healthy participants are reported separately; no ROI-only or resting-state–only limitation. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults with whole-brain task-evoked maps.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (age range 19–38; fMRI subsample n=163) using a social interactive task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) that elicits mentalizing/social cognition. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (ment > cont) and provides whole-brain activation results (tables/figures and cluster-level FWE-corrected maps) for the healthy sample. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply (healthy adults, task-evoked whole-brain maps reported).

This is an fMRI study using a social interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) that probes social-related processing (retaliation/provocation). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=15, mean age 22.3), meeting the 17–65 age criterion and reporting results for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain random-effects analyses with voxelwise statistical maps and tables of Talairach coordinates (decision and outcome phases, parametric modulation), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. Whole-brain thresholding and cluster correction are described and coordinates/activation maps are reported, making the results generalizable to the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of socially-induced emotion regulation (Social-Reg) in healthy adult participants (female, ages 22–32; final N=19), directly addressing social-related processing (social cognition, attachment/affiliation). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Social-Reg > Social-Look; Self-Reg > Self-Look) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-wise FWE correction, plus tables and figures of activation peaks and conjunction/interaction analyses. Results are reported for the healthy sample and are generalizable to healthy adults (not limited to a narrow subgroup). The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not rely exclusively on connectivity or resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: 1) Task: Uses fMRI during a social-related task (Cyberball virtual ball-toss paradigm investigating social interaction/enjoyment). 2) Sample: Healthy adult participants reported separately (final N=31; mean age ~21, within 17–65 range). 3) Whole-brain evidence: Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., ball-toss [high-frequency – normal-frequency] > button-press [high-frequency – normal-frequency]) with coordinates and cluster-level inference (voxelwise p<0.005, cluster-level FWE p<0.05) identifying ventral striatum and precuneus. 4) No exclusion criteria triggered: analyses are not limited to ROIs, not only connectivity/resting-state, and present healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing: tasks explicitly probe social meaning (meaning-related vs physical-property ratings) and self/other, collective/individual distinctions. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=25, mean age 24, right-handed, native speakers) within the 17–65 range. Whole-brain, group-level, univariate task-evoked analyses are reported (random-effects second-level SPM8 results; main contrasts and interaction effects shown; peak coordinates and statistics provided in Table 1; FDR/FWE corrections applied). The paper reports voxelwise contrasts (e.g., meaning > physical, own > other, interaction) generalizable to healthy adults. It does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, resting-state, nor clinical groups only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=23; age 21–43) that uses a task involving social judgments (dominance/trustworthiness), fitting the social-related processing domain. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Social Judgment > Perceptual Judgment) with voxelwise statistics and FWE cluster correction; activation tables and figures are provided. Participants are within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. The study is not ROI-only, nor solely connectivity/resting-state, nor a between-group-only comparison. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24; mean age 25.7, within 17–65). Task is social cognition/theory-of-mind (processing expectations about agents vs objects), satisfying the review’s domain. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., whole-brain random-effects analyses of Background and Outcome segments; Tables 2–3 list peak MNI coordinates and cluster statistics), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. Healthy-group results are clearly described and generalizable to neurotypical adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, not between-group-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (person perception and person knowledge/ToM), using a task manipulating bodies vs names and trait vs neutral information—directly relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Sample: healthy adult participants (n=21; mean age 24.6) within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (main effects of Social Agent and Social Knowledge, and interaction), with thresholding and overlap with functional localisers described and coordinates/tables/figures reported; therefore whole-brain evidence is available for the healthy group. Although the paper also reports PPI connectivity, it additionally provides univariate whole-brain activation maps, so it does not fall under exclusion for ROI- or connectivity-only studies. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (race perception and subsequent trustworthiness evaluations) in healthy adults (30 right-handed White participants, ages 18–29), satisfying the sample criterion (within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (e.g., Black > White contrast) with voxelwise results and tables of coordinates, cluster thresholds, and neuroanatomical labeling, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the study also includes PPI connectivity analyses and ROI discussion, it does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity results; it provides univariate whole-brain maps that are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not a non-empirical paper, and participants are within the eligible age range). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-evaluative processing in healthy adults (N=37, mean age 24.8, within 17–65). The task involved viewing positive, negative, and neutral social-evaluative videos (social communication/understanding of others/self). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (negative > neutral, positive > neutral, conjunction) with FWE-corrected whole-brain results and tables of MNI coordinates, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. ROI analyses are supplementary, but whole-brain voxelwise results are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only; not connectivity-only; includes healthy adult group; empirical original data). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception of others’ facial expressions) in healthy adults (n=24; participants aged ~25). The paper reports group-level, mixed-effects fMRI analyses and explicitly generated parameter-estimate maps for each expression condition and used a group-level whole-brain localiser contrast (faces > scrambled faces) from a large healthy sample (n=83) to define face-selective ROIs. The task is clearly social/communication-related (facial expression perception). Whole-brain, univariate group-level contrasts are described (localiser and group mixed-effects maps), and results from healthy adult participants are reported. It does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=20, mean age 26) that examines social-related processing (responses to empathic vs. unempathic comments). The paper reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., EE>EN, CE>baseline, negative>positive feedback) with tables of coordinates and FWE-corrected cluster results. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (affective theory of mind / perception and understanding of others). Sample: 22 healthy adult participants (21 datasets analyzed), mean age 23.7 (within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (EFE > no EFE, no EFE > EFE, interaction effects) with tables and figures of peak coordinates and whole-brain results, in addition to ROI analyses and PPI. Effects are clearly reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants in age range, empirical original data). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (guilt memory vs hypothetical guilt) in healthy adult participants (n=20 scanned; mean age 25.7). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., guilt memories > neutral memories; whole-brain threshold p<0.001, cluster extent reported) and provides peak coordinates and figures. Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Participants fall within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study is a proof-of-concept rt-fMRI/EEG neurofeedback methods paper focused on correlations between scalp EEG features and activations in a predefined ROI (right pSTS). The abstract and metadata do not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map from healthy adults; analyses appear ROI-based and methodological. Participant/sample details and whole-brain results are not described. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and is excluded.

The provided full text is a brief conference abstract with no details on participants (sample size, ages) or analytic results. It does not report or provide evidence of at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for a healthy adult group (no tables of coordinates, figures, or explicit voxelwise contrasts are described). Because key inclusion criteria (healthy adult sample details and whole-brain task activation results) cannot be verified from the available text, the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social learning in healthy adult participants (final N=26; age range 19–37, all right-handed, no clinical groups). The task is social (learning about others’ generosity) with a non-social control; analyses report group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts and conjunctions (e.g., Gifter > Lottery, parametric SPE and predictability effects) with tables of cluster coordinates and cluster-corrected inference. Results are reported for the healthy/control group separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is empirical and contains original task-evoked whole-brain activation maps rather than ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=20, age 18–27) using a mentalizing task (judging scenarios evoking 60 mental states). It reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain analyses: univariate voxelwise regressions and corrected searchlight MVPA results, with whole-brain statistical maps and cluster-corrected coordinates (Tables S2–S3, Figs. 2–4, SI). Participants are healthy adults and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met, so the study should be included.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=29 final; ages 18–27). The task manipulated perceived live vs. recorded speech to probe social interaction/mentalizing (Social Communication/Perception and Understanding of Others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (Live Story > Social Story; Social > Standard) with statistical thresholds and cluster correction (p<.001, cluster-corrected; Supplementary Table 2 and figures provide reported activations/coordinates). Healthy adult results are reported and generalizable to the healthy group. The study also includes an independent mentalizing localizer and reports whole-brain localizer contrasts. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes within-range ages). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (empathy) in healthy adults (n=26, mean age 30.3, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., sad vs neutral context; multisensory vs unisensory) with tables of coordinates and FWE cluster-corrected results, and a parametric modulation by compassion ratings—fulfilling whole-brain evidence requirement. Although connectivity (DCM) analyses are also present, they are supplementary to and do not replace the reported whole-brain activations. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants are within target age range and results for healthy group are reported). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults using a social task (viewing faces of real-world social network members) probing social cognition and valuation related to popularity. The paper reports whole-brain functional MRI data and group-level effects linking target sociometric popularity to activity in valuation and social cognition systems; results are presented as generalizable healthy-group task effects (main effects/contrasts). It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient groups, or non-empirical work. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (explicit control of interpersonal trust/distrust). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=60; mean age 20.25, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation contrasts (e.g., attitude > age, trust > age, distrust > age; trust > distrust) with FWE-corrected results and coordinate tables and figures, clearly from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. Although ROI and connectivity analyses are also reported, whole-brain task-evoked maps are present (tables/figures). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

The study is an fMRI investigation of social gesture processing in a healthy sample and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task results (cluster-corrected maps and coordinate tables). However, the participant age range is reported as 16.9–25.7 years, meaning at least one participant is under the pre-specified adult lower bound of 17. The paper does not report a separate healthy-adult subgroup analysis excluding the minor. Because the review’s inclusion criteria require that the healthy adult group be within age 17–65, this study does not meet the age criterion and must be excluded despite meeting other criteria (task relevance, healthy sample, whole-brain results).

This is an empirical fMRI hyperscanning study in healthy adult participants (mean ages ~21–23, within 17–65). Tasks are social in nature (mutual gaze, initiating/responding joint attention), fulfilling the social-processing objective. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise results: inter-individual neural synchronization maps (cluster-level FWE-corrected whole-brain results in Tables 2–4 and Figures 3), task-evoked activation maps for eye-blink-related responses (Table 5, Fig. 5), and an EBA localizer (Table 1) — all univariate whole-brain findings generalizable to healthy adults. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only or solely connectivity/seed-based/resting-state approaches. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18 analyzed, ages 18–41) investigating social-communicative processing (comprehension of speech acts/ social communication). Group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses are reported (whole-brain FDR-corrected results and contrasts such as Request > Naming), with coordinates/ROI SVC described. The task is social communication and interpretation of others’ intentions, clearly matching the review constructs. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult sample within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition using a valence classification task contrasting agentic and communal trait words—constructs directly related to social perception/understanding. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=42; ages 18–25) meeting the review age criterion. Analyses: whole-brain, voxelwise GLM contrasts and conjunctions (agency vs fixation, communion vs fixation, implicit baseline), AlphaSim-corrected, with results reported in figures and tables of coordinates. The reported group-level univariate task-evoked maps are clearly from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-connectivity only, and not a non-empirical paper). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (passive viewing of in-/out-group facial expressions—perception/understanding of others, racial prejudice/disgust). (2) Sample: healthy adult participants (N=26 analyzed; mean age 21.2, within 17–65). (3) Whole-brain evidence: group-level, voxelwise univariate analyses are reported (2×2 repeated-measures ANOVA and the interaction contrast ((disgusted out-group–neutral out-group)–(disgusted in-group–neutral in-group)) with whole-brain cluster-corrected results, tables of coordinates and figures). (4) Not excluded: although PPI connectivity is also reported, the paper includes univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) are violated. Therefore INCLUDE.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (Cyberball social exclusion) in healthy adult participants (university students, mean age ~20). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (exclusion vs inclusion) across all participants with tables of coordinates and FWE-corrected thresholds (see Tables 3–4 and whole-brain analyses), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the paper also reports ROI and PPI analyses, it includes unmasked, generalizable whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=28; ages 30–50) that probes social-related processing (implicit social stimulus processing and self-referential processing — relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ and ‘Others’). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task contrasts (main effects, conjunctions, and direct contrasts) with FDR-corrected thresholds and cluster extent, clearly attributable to the healthy sample. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or a between-group-only study. Participants fall within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy/control group are reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=26, age 19–26) that employed a task manipulating social content (Social vs Non-social) during reading. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Social>Non-social; Vivid>Abstract) with cluster-corrected results and tables of peak coordinates and figures, clearly identified as coming from the healthy participant group. Analyses are task-evoked and generalizable to healthy adults (within the 17–65 range). The study also reports behavioral measures in the same healthy sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (observers viewing violent dyadic interactions) in healthy adults (15 male participants, N=14 analyzed; mean age 23.6, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain GLM contrasts (e.g., all conditions vs baseline; focus on aggressor vs focus on victim) with statistical maps and tabulated coordinates (figures and Supplementary Table S2), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task is social (perception/understanding of others; empathy/aggression modulation). The report is not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses and presents healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (empathy for others’ pain) with a minimal-group manipulation. Sample: 30 healthy adults aged 18–35 (within 17–65 range). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results: a main effect of pain with FWE-corrected whole-brain clusters and multiple whole-brain contrast/interactions (tables of coordinates and cluster results are provided). Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches, and results for the healthy control group are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study is an fMRI investigation in healthy adult participants and reports whole-brain task-evoked results (HA− > Neutral contrast) meeting the imaging and sample criteria, the experimental task is passive emotional picture viewing (IAPS) designed to probe negative emotion processing. The task does not explicitly target social-related constructs (e.g., affiliation/attachment, social communication, explicit perception/understanding of self or others); the brief person-detection button-press served as an attentional check rather than a social-cognitive judgment. While the authors discuss dmPFC involvement in social cognition, the task itself is not a social processing paradigm. Therefore it fails the core inclusion requirement that the study use a social-related task and is excluded from the social-processing meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) using validated animated stimuli contrasting ToM vs random movement. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=20; ages 24–64), which falls within the 17–65 inclusion range. The manuscript reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., ToM > R and ToM > Baseline) with statistical thresholds and reported activations (tables/figures), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and presents univariate task activation maps for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of gaze-following (social attention) in healthy adults (N=28, ages 18–29). The task probes social-related processing (gaze-mediated orienting to political in-group/out-group faces). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (incongruent>congruent) with voxel coordinates and cluster-level FWE-corrected results in tables and figures, and extracts ROI results but not solely ROI. Participants fall within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy sample are reported separately. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain task-evoked maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study (NeuroImage, 2015) using the EmpaToM task probing socio-affective (empathy, compassion) and socio-cognitive (Theory of Mind) processing in healthy adults. Samples include healthy adult groups (Experiment 1a N=25; Experiment 2 N=178, mean age 40.9, range within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task contrasts (e.g., emotionally negative > neutral videos; ToM > nonToM questions) with tables of MNI coordinates and statistical thresholds (including p<.05 FWE-corrected results in Experiment 2). Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not exclusively connectivity/resting-state, and provides the required whole-brain task activation maps; therefore it meets inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (social reputation) in healthy adults (N=28, ages 20–24, 14M/14F). The task involved viewing faces paired with positive/negative reputational comments and rating pleasantness — a social cognitive task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (positive vs. neutral; negative vs. neutral; conjunction; and (positive vs. neutral) vs (negative vs. neutral)) with statistical thresholds (voxel p<0.001, cluster-level FWE p<0.05) and a table of peak coordinates. Results are presented for the healthy participant group (not restricted to a subgroup). The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Although the sample size is modest (noted by authors), that does not violate inclusion criteria. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of task-evoked whole-brain fMRI in healthy adults.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI during a social-related task (viewing social vs non-social scenes), with a healthy adult sample (N=33, ages 18–21). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (social > non-social contrast) with FDR-corrected maps and a table of MNI coordinates, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only; not connectivity- or resting-state-only; includes appropriate age range). Therefore it should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study probing the urge to imitate others’ actions—a social-cognitive process (perception/understanding of others, imitation). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=37, ages 18–25), meeting the age and health criteria. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (parametric modulation, one-sample t-tests, cluster-corrected thresholds) with coordinates and figures, fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although PPI connectivity is included, the study also provides univariate whole-brain activation maps (not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.
