This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (mentalizing/theory-of-mind) using an interactive Prisoner’s Dilemma task. The sample includes 164 healthy adult subjects and reports task-evoked brain activation (group-level univariate results) across the canonical mentalizing network (bilateral precuneus, cingulate cortices, temporal poles, IFG, TPJ, medial frontal gyri, amygdala, etc.), indicating whole-brain task effects generalizable to healthy adults. The paper reports correlations of attachment dimensions with task-associated neural activity, not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and presents whole-brain findings suitable for inclusion. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-connectivity-only, not only between-group contrasts). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain fMRI social task studies.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (why/how action understanding; engages mentalizing/theory-of-mind networks). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=17, ages 21–46) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses and thresholded whole-brain results (cluster-level FWE correction) with tables/figures describing significant clusters; whole-brain contrasts are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only; not connectivity/resting-state only; healthy adult results are reported).

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants and examines social-related tasks (ToM, face/voice perception, biological motion, language), all group-level task analyses were explicitly restricted to a bilateral STS mask rather than reported as unmasked whole-brain voxelwise task activation maps. The paper therefore does not provide an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group (resting-state connectivity and masked/ROI-limited results do not satisfy the ‘whole-brain’ inclusion criterion). Excluded for failing the whole-brain evidence requirement.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (observed eye contact and gaze following). Sample: healthy adults (N=21, mean age 24.6, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Eye Contact > Averted Gaze, Congruent > Incongruent, interaction contrasts) with thresholding and tables/figures of coordinates and cluster statistics; analyses used SPM8 GLM and whole-brain inference (cluster-level correction via Monte Carlo). No ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical limitations apply. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social working memory (social cognition) in a healthy adult sample (N=25; mean age 21.6). The task explicitly manipulates social content (trait-based reordering) versus a non-social control and reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (parametric modulation, contrasts SWM vs CWM, conjunctions) with cluster and voxelwise thresholds, tables of activated clusters, and surface-rendered maps. Results for the healthy participant group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=63; ages 20.4–36.6) that uses a social incentive delay task probing social vs monetary reward processing. The paper reports group-level, univariate task-evoked whole-brain activation results (e.g., reward>neutral, social>monetary contrasts) with tables of coordinates and FWE-corrected voxelwise results, and figures of activations. Results for the healthy control cohort are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes whole-brain task activation maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (mimicry, affiliation, emotion, and group membership) in healthy adult participants (N=41, mean age ~22.6). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Incongruent > Congruent and condition-specific masked contrasts) with cluster-level multiple-comparison correction and provides tables of activation coordinates. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and results are reported for the healthy/control sample. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social attribution (why/how task) in a healthy adult sample (N=19; ages 21–46). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (e.g., conjunctions and interaction contrasts for why>how across social and nonsocial stimuli), with cluster-level family-wise-error correction and coordinate tables (Table 2) and downloadable group contrast images (NeuroVault/OSF). Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, not only between-group contrasts, and participants fall within the 17–65 range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (19 pairs; 38 individuals; ages 18–33) using a face-to-face eye-contact task—clearly a social-related paradigm (social interaction/mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise GLM results for Task A and B and paired t-test contrasts to define exogenous/endogenous systems, with whole-brain statistical maps (thresholds reported, cluster reporting, atlas labels, MNI coordinates). Whole-brain, univariate task-evoked maps are described and used to create CCRI masks; atlas labels and coordinates are provided. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state only, and presents generalizable group maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult dyads (joint attention task) and reports whole-sample ICA spatial maps implicating social regions (rTPJ), it does not present a group-level, univariate, voxelwise task-evoked activation map (e.g., INT vs NoINT GLM contrast) for the healthy/control group. The analyses are data-driven ICA and cross-brain coupling/permutation tests (component spatial maps and connectivity indices) rather than conventional whole-brain GLM task activation maps or coordinate tables for univariate effects. Per the review’s inclusion criteria, at least one group-level univariate whole-brain task map is required; this criterion is not met. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=18, ages 18–44) investigating prediction of others’ behavior (theory-of-mind vs deontic reasoning). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses with tables of coordinates and cluster-corrected results (see Tables 2 and 3, whole-brain and small-volume corrections, and multiple whole-brain contrasts/figures). It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses, and results for the healthy adult sample are reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related—an interactive sender–receiver game probing deception, intention to deceive, and theory-of-mind/social cognition (perception/understanding of others). (2) Sample: healthy adult participants (N=34, age range 21–32) with results reported for the healthy group. (3) Whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation maps are reported: GLM-based contrasts (e.g., simple deception > truth, sophisticated deception > truth, truth > deception) analyzed at the second level using Bayesian whole-brain probability maps, with coordinates and tables/figures provided. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, not between-group-only). Therefore include.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (perception of emotional crowds and social interactions). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=16, ages 19–27). Analysis: group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses are reported (main effects and interactions), with cluster-corrected results presented in Tables 1–3 and whole-brain figures. The paper reports task-evoked voxelwise activation maps (univariate contrasts/ANOVAs) for the healthy participant group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, healthy adult sample within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social perception in healthy adults (n=12, ages 21–31) using a social-related task (viewing and sex-categorizing person dyads with congruent/incongruent interactions). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain GLM analyses with voxelwise and cluster-level thresholds and provides peak coordinates and cluster details (Table 3, Figures 6–7), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for the healthy/control group are presented and generalizable within the reported sample. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social communication (feeling addressed by co-speech gestures and body orientation). Sample: 37 healthy right-handed native German adults (age range 20–39), meeting the 17–65 healthy adult criterion. The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., IC>NG, ego>allo, interaction contrasts) with cluster-level correction and tables of peak MNI coordinates, and reports behavioral correlations with BOLD—i.e., whole-brain activation maps for the healthy group are clearly described. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor restricted to clinical groups. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The provided full text is a brief conference abstract with insufficient methodological detail: it does not report participant characteristics (age range or confirmation of a healthy adult group) nor present any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or coordinate tables for a healthy/control group. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one clearly reported whole-brain healthy-group task activation map and explicit reporting of healthy adult participants, this study cannot be confirmed to meet those requirements and must be excluded.

The study used task-based fMRI to examine neural responses to social language (social communication/mentalizing). Participants were healthy adult undergraduates (n=19; mean age 20.6, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (parametric whole-brain maps and thresholded clusters; Figures 5 and 6; Tables 4 and 6) in addition to ROI analyses. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and generalizable within that population. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults investigating social cognition (joint attention: initiating and responding). Participants were healthy adults (final N=13, mean age 24.85) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., RJA - RJAc, IJA - IJAc), conjunctions, and tables of MNI coordinates with FDR-corrected statistics and SPM maps, clearly attributed to the healthy/control group. The task is clearly social-related (social interaction, gaze-contingent virtual avatar). No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not only between-group contrasts, and not a non-empirical paper). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI evidence in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social communication/mutual understanding in healthy adults (54 right-handed male participants, ages 18–27). The task is explicitly social (creation and negotiation of shared meanings between Communicator and Addressee). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (model-based whole-brain search for BOLD dynamics matching behavioral mutual understanding; random-effects analysis with cluster-level correction, reported regional findings including rSTG), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Healthy adult results are reported separately and are generalizable (random-effects, whole-brain inference). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (dynamic social tie formation during a repeated public-good game). Sample: healthy adult participants (25 scanned subjects, ages ~22–23), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate GLM results (parametric modulations of tie, impulse, contribution magnitude) with reported MNI coordinates and cluster-wise FWE correction (initial z=2.3, cluster p<0.05), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Although connectivity (PPI, beta-seed) is also reported, whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group are clearly provided. No ROI-only, no patient-only, and not a non-empirical paper. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication in healthy adults. Task: participants viewed text messages believed to be sent by a friend or a computer (social communication/mentalizing paradigm). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=18, females, age 19–28) reported separately and analyzed as a healthy group. Whole-brain evidence: group-level univariate whole-brain contrasts are reported (friend > computer; results presented in Table 2 and Fig. 3A), based on random-effects inference with cluster correction; coordinates and cluster sizes are provided. The paper therefore provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy group. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and not a non-empirical paper. No exclusion criteria are violated. Conclusion: meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults and should be included in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (social sharing/affiliation) in healthy adults (participants aged 20–33; behavioral n=58, fMRI n=26). The task manipulated social context (shared vs unshared viewing with a friend) and evoked task-related activations. Group-level, random-effects whole-brain analyses were performed and reported (e.g., exploratory whole-brain activations in left DLPFC and bilateral precuneus; main effects emotional > neutral reported across the whole brain with cluster-level correction). Although ROI analyses (VS, OFC) were used, whole-brain univariate task contrasts from the healthy sample are presented and generalized to the healthy adult group (shared_emo > unshared_emo and other contrasts). The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (explicit labeling of others’ emotional facial expressions). Sample: 50 healthy adults aged 18–29 (within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (HA>NE, AN>NE, FE>NE) and multiple second-level regression models, with cluster-level FWE correction and tables of peak coordinates. Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (biological motion) in healthy adults (N=26 analyzed; ages 18–39). The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate analyses: whole-brain biological-motion-selectivity analyses projected to a FreeSurfer average surface with correction for multiple comparisons (Monte Carlo simulation) and a significant cluster in right pSTS is reported. Although ROI analyses are also performed, whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy adult sample are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria apply (not resting-state-only, not clinical-only, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of cross-modal person recognition in healthy adults (n=16, ages 20–31) addressing social processing (recognition of others). However, although the paper reports group-level random-effects analyses, the reported significant task-evoked effects are ROI-restricted (OFA, FFA, aTL) and corrected for the ROI; the authors explicitly state that there were no significant results at P<0.05 FWE-corrected for the whole brain without the covariate. Main reported findings rely on ROI-based contrasts and PPI connectivity; no unmasked, whole-brain group-level voxelwise task activation map (or thresholded whole-brain coordinates) generalizable to the healthy adult group is presented. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for whole-brain evidence (and effectively reports only ROI/seed-based results), so it must be excluded from the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (20 right-handed male volunteers, ages 20–28) that uses task-based functional MRI while participants viewed social/empathy-evoking campaign videos versus neutral control videos. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (CV > NV) with FWE-corrected results and peak coordinates, and subsequent ROI analyses relating activation (notably in bilateral STS) to behavioural empathy measures. All inclusion criteria are met: social-related task, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and clearly reported whole-brain task activation maps. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy-only samples) are violated.

The study reports an fMRI investigation of interpersonal synchrony (a social-affiliation task) in healthy adult participants (total N=100 across studies, including a neuroimaging component). The abstract and highlights explicitly state involvement of multiple whole-brain regions (e.g., areas implicated in social cognition, embodied cognition, action observation such as ACC, dmPFC, IPL, premotor/supplementary motor areas), indicating group-level, task-evoked activation results rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. There is no indication the sample is clinical or outside the 17–65 range, nor that results are limited to between-group contrasts or non-whole-brain analyses. Based on the available full-text excerpt, the paper meets all inclusion criteria for an fMRI whole-brain task study of social processing in healthy adults. Confidence is slightly reduced because the provided excerpt does not show the full methods/results tables (e.g., coordinate tables), but the language strongly implies whole-brain univariate findings were reported.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final MRI n=16; mean age 22.7) using a social cognition task (implicit/explicit false-belief ‘Sally–Anne’ movies) that probes perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (explicit ToM localizer: belief > photo/map contrast with cluster-thresholded SPM and peak Talairach coordinates; implicit false-belief > true-belief whole-brain SPM reported and shown in figures). Results are presented as group-level voxelwise contrasts with coordinates and figures, generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (impression formation/person evaluation). Sample includes healthy adults (n=20 males, ages 19–31). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain voxelwise analyses (exploratory whole-brain ANOVA; activations and coordinates reported in Table 1 and figures; contrasts versus fixation), not ROI-only results. The task and contrasts are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adult perceivers. No exclusion criteria are violated (not resting-state/connectivity-only, not clinical-only, ages within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (n=16, ages 18–25) using a social competitive task (matching-pennies vs human, android, robots, computer). Analyses report group-level, whole-brain, univariate GLM results (random-effects one-sample t-tests; voxel-wise threshold p<.001 with cluster FWE correction) and list peak coordinates/tables for activations modulated by impression components. Healthy adult results are reported separately and are generalizable to the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not between-group-only). Therefore the paper satisfies all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI evidence in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social-interaction task (an adapted Taylor Aggression Paradigm presenting opponent video clips) probing perception of others and social communication. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (32 included; mean age 23.3, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., angry > neutral) with cluster-wise FWE correction and tables of activation clusters (decision and outcome phases). Although ROIs were used for specific hypotheses, whole-brain results are clearly reported and generalizable to the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, empirical original data in healthy adults). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of a social task (ultimatum game) in healthy adult participants (n=28, mean age 25) and reports group-level task contrasts, the second-level analyses were conducted within a restricted mask of 16 bilateral ROIs (wfu_pickatlas) rather than as an unmasked whole-brain voxelwise analysis. The inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map generalizable to healthy adults. Because the reported results are ROI-masked (not whole‑brain/unmasked), the study does not meet the whole‑brain evidence requirement and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=19, age 18–35) using a social triadic imagination task (self/other/triad/iron). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., triad > iron; conjunction triad ∩ self ∩ other) with coordinates and family-wise error corrected thresholds (p<0.05 FWE) and tables of peak activations. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy sample are clearly reported. Participants are within the 17–65 range and no ROI-only or resting-state-only analyses limit inclusion. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults assessing social-related processing.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ten right‑handed males, ages 22–32) investigating perception/understanding of others’ social interactions using point‑light biological motion. The paper reports group‑level, voxelwise whole‑brain univariate contrasts (e.g., (atypical‑upright+atypical‑inverted) – (typical‑upright+typical‑inverted)) with cluster‑level correction and tables of activation coordinates, plus figures and ROI/GCM follow‑ups. The task is social‑related (third‑person perspective of social interaction) and results are clearly reported for the healthy adult group. Not limited to ROI‑only or connectivity‑only analyses; whole‑brain task activation maps are presented and generalizable to healthy adults within the 17–65 range. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta‑analysis.

Study reports fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=20 males, mean age 24.6) performing a social-related task (viewing first-person video clips of neutral, social-positive, and reactive-aggressive interactions). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts are reported (multiple contrasts and conjunctions; p<.05 FDR-corrected; tables of peak coordinates provided), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results pertain to the healthy adult sample (no separate clinical-only reporting). The paper is empirical with original fMRI data and does not report only ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses. Age range and sample type meet inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social influence in healthy adults (mean age ~24; right-handed students; N=20 scanned). The task is explicitly social/interactive (pair-based communication of arousal ratings) and addresses social-related processing (social appraisal/conformity). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects), with voxelwise results surviving clusterwise FWE correction reported in tables and figures (insula, DLPFC, ventral striatum, amygdala), including parametric modulators and whole-brain contrasts. Results for the healthy/control group are presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This paper reports an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (German and Chinese groups) using a social feedback task that probes perception/understanding of self and others (social cognition). fMRI acquisition and preprocessing are described, and group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results are reported (e.g., main effect contrasts and parametric modulators with voxelwise FWE-corrected clusters and coordinate tables). Results are clearly presented for the healthy sample and generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and includes whole-brain activation maps/coordinates, meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults: N=21 healthy right-handed adults (Mage=23.1). The task probes social cognition (self-referential moral processing and intergroup competition) using task-evoked fMRI. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses with corrected thresholds and tables of coordinates (see Table 2 and supplementary materials) in addition to ROI analyses. Whole-brain contrasts (e.g., main effects and self>other) are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not resting-state/seed-only; healthy adult sample within 17–65; empirical fMRI data reported). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (conceptual and agentic self-referential recollection). Sample: 18 healthy adult participants (mean age 22.5, range 19–29), meeting the 17–65 healthy adult criterion. The paper reports group-level, univariate voxelwise analyses including whole-brain results (whole-brain FWE-corrected clusters for old>new and other contrasts are reported) in addition to ROI analyses, so it is not ROI-only. Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., patient-only sample, ROI-only, resting-state-only) are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=26, mean age 20.7, within 17–65). It uses task-based fMRI during social paradigms (Cyberball exclusion and a modified Dictator Game) probing social processes (exclusion, punishment, forgiveness). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Excluders > Includers; Excluders equality > Includers equality) with tables of coordinates and mentions FDR-corrected clusters; results are clearly reported for the healthy sample. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attribution of awareness to another person) in healthy adults (fMRI sample n=50, ages 18–49). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (H trials – E trials) with correction for multiple comparisons, surface-projected maps, and a table of Talairach coordinates, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The social task clearly probes perception/understanding of others. Results for the healthy/control group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses, nor is it a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (causal attributions/mentalizing) in healthy adults (N=20, ages 18–41). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., self/other/situation > baseline) with a whole-brain ANOVA and provides voxel coordinates and cluster-level statistics (Table 1) and conjunction/contrast maps, indicating generalizable healthy-group activation maps. It is not ROI-only, resting-state, connectivity-only, nor between-group-only. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and healthy; results for the healthy group are reported directly. Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis of fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (bystander effect) in healthy adults (n=17, ages 18–27). The task is social-related (witnessing an emergency while performing a color-naming task). The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects GLM, parametric and contrasts) with cluster- and FDR-corrected statistical maps and tables of Talairach coordinates (Tables 1–3), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and not limited to between-group contrasts. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study includes an fMRI social-closeness task in healthy participants, the fMRI results are reported only as ROI-based analyses (beta weights extracted from pre-defined ROIs) rather than group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps. In addition, the sample is mixed adolescents and adults (ages 12–30) and the paper does not present whole-brain results separately for an adult-only (17–65) healthy group. Therefore it fails the meta-analysis requirement to report at least one healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and should be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=15, ages 20–28) that includes a social-distance task (names/photos of friends vs acquaintances) tapping social perception/understanding. The paper reports whole-brain analyses: a conventional univariate GLM and group-level voxelwise t tests (sooner vs later; closer vs farther; more vs less familiar) conducted across the whole brain; authors explicitly report the univariate results (no voxels survived FDR correction) and describe the group-level searchlight and RSA results. Although univariate effects were null, the study clearly performed and reported group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses for the healthy adult sample. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the eligible age range. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (subset N=22; ages ~18.9 within 17–65). The fMRI paradigm contrasted faces versus houses (a social face-perception task relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’). Authors performed whole-brain, group-level second-level GLM analyses and report significant voxelwise clusters (Table 2; p = 0.05 FWE corrected) in bilateral fusiform gyrus and right inferior frontal gyrus. Whole-brain suprathreshold voxel counts and coordinates are described, satisfying the requirement for univariate, voxelwise healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and includes original fMRI data in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, and reports within-group healthy results). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of online social interaction (reciprocal imitation) in healthy adults (N=23, right-handed females, age 18–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (imitating vs rest, being imitated vs rest, observation vs rest) with familywise error correction and provides coordinates, tables, and figures of activation maps. Although the paper also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it clearly reports whole-brain GLM results for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within the 17–65 age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI comparing responses to familiar (partner, child, friend) versus unfamiliar faces in a healthy control group (n=13). The task probes social/person-related processing (affiliation/attachment and perception/understanding of others). The paper provides group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts for the control group (e.g., partner > unfamiliar faces with FWE-corrected whole-brain results and coordinates). Although the sample is older adults (mean age 64.5 ±5.7), a healthy control group is reported separately from the clinical case, satisfying the criterion that healthy-group whole-brain task effects are available. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social decision-making (cooperation, trust, social value orientation, mentalizing) in healthy adult participants (mean age 24.6; n=35 after exclusions). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain GLM contrasts (e.g., proself vs prosocial, cooperate vs defect) with cluster-corrected whole-brain results presented in tables, figures, and text. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes healthy adult whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI results, only connectivity, non-empirical) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an original task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=15; males aged 21–40) that explicitly investigates social cognition (empathy, Theory of Mind, self–other differentiation). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (ANOVA, contrasts, conjunctions) with cluster thresholds and coordinate tables/figures (e.g., main effects, interactions, peak coordinates), clearly attributed to the healthy/control sample. Participants fall within the 17–65 range and results are not restricted to a narrow subgroup. The study is empirical and not ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=27, mean age 34.1, right-handed, no psychiatric/neurological history) that used a social communication task (multimodal emotional communication: facial expression, prosody, speech content). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise GLM whole-brain contrasts (channel-specific contrasts, conjunctions) and displays whole-brain activation maps and coordinates used to define ROIs. Although the reanalysis emphasizes FIR and DCM, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results for the healthy group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, clinical-only group) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of explicit social judgments (trustworthiness and attractiveness) using vocal stimuli in a sample of healthy adults (N=44, ages 21–60). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and cluster-level corrected results with MNI coordinates (see Table 1 and figures). The task assesses social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes whole-brain maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study uses task-based fMRI of live verbal communication (social communication). Sample comprises 22 healthy adult right-handed women (mean age 27.2), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (first-level regressors and second-level voxel-wise t-tests with cluster correction), with activation maps, figures and supplementary tables of coordinates. It is empirical fMRI data in healthy adults and does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This paper reports structural MRI (voxel-based morphometry) correlates of proneness to moral sentiments using T1-weighted images and behavioral VMST measures in healthy adults. It does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked fMRI statistical maps from the healthy/control group. Although the authors reference and use previously acquired SSC-BOLD peak values from an earlier fMRI study in a subset (N=29) as regressors, this manuscript itself does not provide whole-brain task activation maps or contrasts generalizable to the healthy adult population. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring reporting of whole-brain task-evoked fMRI results.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults: 32 healthy participants (ages 18–39) underwent task-based fMRI while performing socially framed collaborative, individual, and competitive effort tasks. The contrasts include whole-brain, group-level univariate SPM results (parametric modulations and contrasts) reported with clusterwise FWE correction and tables/figures of activations (e.g., ventral basal ganglia, TPJ, mPFC). The task probes perception/understanding of others and social motivation (social cognition constructs). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants are within 17–65). Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study explicitly investigating social-related processing (natural social vs nonsocial gestures) using dynamic stimuli. Sample: 20 healthy participants (mean age 21.4; range 16.9–25.7) — majority adult; results for the healthy group are reported. Whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise analyses were performed and reported (TFCE with permutation testing; contrasts and cluster results presented in figures/tables and supplementary material). The paper is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Note: one participant is slightly under 17 (16.9), but the sample is otherwise adult and results are reported for the healthy group; this does not materially conflict with the inclusion requirement. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This paper reports multiple task-based fMRI experiments in healthy adult participants (female undergraduates, ages within adult range). The paradigm is social/empathic (emotional egocentricity bias) and involves group-level, univariate task contrasts (e.g., (Other Incongruent > Congruent) > (Self Incongruent > Congruent)) with reported peak coordinates and cluster statistics (Table 2, coordinates MNI 68/-38/36) and whole-brain analyses (exploratory whole-brain in fMRI1 and SVC-informed inference in fMRI2, with coordinates provided). Although PPI and SVC were used, the manuscript includes univariate, voxelwise task-evoked group contrasts for the healthy control samples; results are presented as coordinates/tables and discussed at whole-brain level. Participants are healthy adults and results for healthy group are reported separately. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults investigating social processing.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (evaluation of face approachability—perception/understanding of others) in (presumably) healthy adult participants. The abstract and text report group-level task contrasts (interaction between task and face valence) identifying activations in left amygdala and frontal gyri and BOLD correlations with trait anxiety, indicating univariate, whole-brain task-evoked results generalizable to healthy adults. No evidence the sample is exclusively outside the 17–65 range or that only ROI/ connectivity/ between-group-only analyses were performed. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult group, whole-brain univariate results).

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (attribute framing and self/other perspective taking) in healthy adults (n=21; ages 19–41). It reports within-group, task-evoked, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (GLM; contrasts such as task vs control, positive vs negative frame, frame-inconsistent vs frame-consistent) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-size correction, and lists peak coordinates and rendered images. Results are clearly presented for the healthy participant group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity or between-group contrasts. All inclusion criteria are satisfied, and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This paper is a non-empirical review/theoretical article (discusses recent findings and prospects) and does not report original fMRI data from a healthy adult sample. The full text and abstract describe review content and theoretical discussion rather than methods, participants, or group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked results. No sample characteristics, task-based fMRI methods, or whole-brain statistical maps/coordinate tables for a healthy adult group are provided. Therefore it fails the inclusion criteria requiring original fMRI data with at least one whole-brain, group-level task activation map and meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (male drivers, ages ~19–30) using task-based fMRI while participants viewed social/traffic campaign videos designed to elicit social-cognitive processes (empathy, mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (campaign videos vs neutral videos) for the participant groups, with whole-brain maps/figures and tables of coordinate clusters, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked results. Results for healthy control/safe-driver group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI task involves social cognition (third-party punishment, mentalizing/attribution of others' intentions), performed in healthy adult sample (N=26, mean age 26 within 17–65), and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (random-effects GLM; reported whole-brain FDR threshold q<0.05) with peak coordinates (R TPJ, R anterior insula) described in the text/figures. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, healthy-group whole-brain results clearly reported).

This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (participants aged 19–28; initial N=45 with group-level analyses on 31–35 subjects). The tasks target social-related processes (implicit/explicit detection of eye-gaze shifts and self-propelling motion; an implicit mental-inference role-playing task). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., E–O and S–X), provides peak coordinates and cluster statistics in tables and figures, and applies correction for multiple comparisons. Results for the healthy/control group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, resting-state, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an original, task-based fMRI study of social cognition (impression formation) in healthy adults (N=19, mean age 19.1, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate task contrasts and provides whole-brain results with Talairach coordinates and cluster correction (Tables 1 and 2), not solely ROI or connectivity analyses. The social task directly targets perception/understanding of others and uses an established functional localizer plus main task analyses generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI, only connectivity, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception (processing nonverbal dyadic interactions) in healthy adults (n=21 males, ages 23–33). The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others), and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and tables of activation coordinates (e.g., contingent>mirrored, rigid>smooth, meaningful>scrambled) with cluster-level correction. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes whole-brain statistical maps/coordinate tables generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind/emotion/pain judgments) in healthy adults (N=46 female, ages 18–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and cluster-corrected results (tables of coordinates and whole-brain maps are provided), fulfilling the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. The task and constructs (mentalizing, perception/understanding of others) are clearly social-related. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, healthy adult sample within age range).

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (recognition of 'vitality forms', i.e., perceiving others’ affective/cognitive action style). Sample: 19 healthy adult participants (ages 21–29), meeting the age and healthy sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (what/how vs baseline; how vs what) with MNI coordinates and PFWE-corrected results in tables and figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be included.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: fMRI during a social-related task (message communication, mentalizing, and social influence paradigms tapping perception/understanding of others and social communication). (2) Sample: Healthy adult participants reported (interns N=19, producers N=79; mean ages ~20.5, within 17–65). (3) Whole-brain evidence: Group-level, random-effects, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses are reported (whole-brain thresholds, MNI coordinates, Table 1 and figures reported). (4) No exclusion criteria apply: results are not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are presented and generalizable. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=31, ages 18–26) using a social-related task (winning/losing for self, best friend, or an antagonist). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (repeated-measures ANOVAs) with tables of MNI coordinates and statistical thresholds; several effects survive FDR/FWE or are reported with small-volume correction. Results for the healthy participant group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not violate any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes participants within 17–65, is empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (ages 18–45) using a social task (viewing images of human suffering vs neutral while applying compassion or reappraisal). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task analyses (contrasts of suffering vs neutral; second‑level whole-brain Group×Redistribution interaction and within-group change maps), with corrected whole‑brain results and reported cluster coordinates/figures (IPC, DLPFC, NAcc). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state, and reports univariate task-evoked maps from healthy adult participants. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social communication (imitation of communicative vs non-social/meaningless gestures). Sample: healthy adults (n=20 reported; right-handed males, mean age 24.6), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (SPM5), with Monte Carlo cluster correction and tables/peak MNI coordinates for multiple contrasts (e.g., IMI>CT, S>NS, interactions). Results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps and coordinate tables, generalizable to a healthy adult population. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and is empirical. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of laughter perception, a social-communication/mentalizing task (perception and understanding of others). Participants: 18 healthy right-handed adults (mean age 26), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., CSL>TIC, TIC>CSL, CAT>COU) analyzed with second-level random-effects SPM analyses and cluster-level FWE correction; results are described across whole-brain maps and ROI conjunctions. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only (although PPI connectivity analyses are also performed), and presents whole-brain task-evoked activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=23, mean age 24) investigating social communication (communicative vs private intentions). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., CInt > PInt; interaction effects) with tables of peak coordinates and statistical thresholds, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the study also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it additionally provides the required univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only samples, or non-empirical) are met.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults: participants (scanned N=38; ages 19–31) completed a speed-dating paradigm and were scanned while learning partners' decisions. Imaging methods report group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (multiple tables and figures: e.g., main effect Yes>No, Mismatch>Match, Match>Unrequited, anticipation contrasts) with MNI coordinates and cluster-level statistics thresholded to control whole-brain FWE. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample (not limited to a narrow subgroup), and are not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing about groups and individuals) in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: n=25, ages 19–27; Experiment 2: n=14, ages 18–23). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., group mental > group physical; member mental > member physical; individual mental > individual physical) with tables of peak coordinates, cluster sizes, and corrected thresholds, and includes whole-brain maps and a false-belief localizer. Results are reported for healthy/control samples and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adults during a social task (cyberball) and reports ROI-based and multivariate (MVPA/searchlight) results, it does not provide a group-level univariate whole-brain voxelwise task activation map for the healthy group. The reported whole-brain analysis is an exploratory multivariate searchlight (correlation-based) and the authors state that univariate SPM group analyses for the learning × valence interaction did not yield significant voxels after correction. Thus the paper fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map generalizable to healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (beauty/attractiveness comparisons of people) in a healthy adult sample (25 right-handed British women, mean age 23.46). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (ANOVA, conjunction analyses) with voxelwise results and tables of MNI coordinates and statistical maps; whole-brain results are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and presents within-group healthy-participant contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study with 24 healthy adult participants (ages 18–27). Tasks probe construal-level processes including ‘why/how’ action identification and categories/exemplars; contrasts engage social-cognition-related processes (mentalizing/default-mode and mirror/action networks), fitting ‘perception and understanding of others/self’ constructs. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., How>Why, Exemplars>Categories, conjunctions) with corrected cluster thresholds and tables of coordinates (Table 2), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not between-group-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=17, mean age 23.5) that uses a social decision-making task probing interpersonal conflict (human vs computer opponents). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Conflict>No Conflict; interaction Human>Computer) with statistical maps and coordinate tables across the brain (dMFC, AI, vlPFC, etc.). Results for the healthy/control group are reported and generalizable; analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity/resting-state only. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study (with an accompanying ALE meta-analysis) investigating person knowledge/face familiarity—a social cognition domain (perception/understanding of others, affiliation/social closeness). Participants are healthy adults within the 17–65 range (empirical sample: 15 females, mean age ~22; meta-analysis comprised healthy young adults). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects GLM, ALE meta-analysis), voxelwise results and Talairach coordinates, and whole-brain corrected maps/contrasts (e.g., famous vs. novel landmarks; familiar vs. unfamiliar faces). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed connectivity only, and provides results generalizable to healthy adults. Although the empirical sample is female-only, healthy adult whole-brain results are reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an original task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n≈36, mean age ≈21) that examines neural responses to others’ pain (a social-cognitive/‘perception and understanding of others’ paradigm). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (painful vs non-painful) with FDR-corrected results and provides coordinate tables and whole-brain activations (Table 3, figures, and text). Results for the healthy adult sample are reported separately and are generalizable to the healthy adult population. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study manipulating sociality (trustworthiness judgments) and working memory load in healthy adult participants (initial N=16; imaging analyses N=14; mean age 22). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (2×2 repeated-measures ANOVA) with cluster correction and tables of peak coordinates and cluster sizes for main effects and interactions. The task and contrasts are clearly social-related (perception/understanding of others) and results are presented for the healthy sample. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes generalizable healthy-group task activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition contrasting interactive vs. observational conditions using dynamic video stimuli. Sample: 22 healthy adult participants (mean age 25) within the 17–65 range. Group-level, task-evoked analyses were conducted (two group RFX whole-brain ANOVAs) and reported; although ROI small-volume corrections were emphasized for main effects, the authors also report exploratory whole-brain results (early visual/V1) and describe group-level task effects thresholded at p<0.05 FWE. Thus the paper reports univariate, group-level task-evoked maps from healthy adults during a social-related task and meets the inclusion criteria (not limited to ROI/connectivity-only results).

This is an fMRI study in a healthy adult sample (N=21, mean age 24) using an action-observation/execution paradigm probing mirror representations—directly relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ (a social-processing construct). The paper reports group-level, univariate task-evoked activation and adaptation effects, including a whole-brain analysis (threshold p<0.001 uncorrected) with peak coordinates and SPM figures, in addition to ROI results. Therefore it provides generalizable, healthy-group whole-brain task effects and meets all inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI results, only connectivity/resting-state, non-healthy sample) are violated.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition (visual perspective taking/theory of mind). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=16 after exclusions; mean age 22.4), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Inconsistent Other > Consistent Other; Consistent Self > Consistent Other) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster-level FWE-corrected results, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task clearly probes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others’ perspectives). It does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses, nor is it a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition (action understanding, mentalizing, mirror system) in healthy adults (N=19, ages 18–32). The authors report group-level, random-effects univariate analyses of task contrasts (load × goal; conjunctions and contrasts) and provide cluster coordinates (Table 1) for reported effects. Although main corrected results are reported within an a priori mask of mirror and mentalizing systems, the manuscript states that whole-brain results and details about the mask are provided in the Supplemental Methods, and coordinates for group-level activation are reported; thus the paper provides healthy-group, voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps/coordinates rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. All inclusion criteria are met (task fMRI, healthy adult sample, group-level univariate results with reported coordinates/whole-brain information). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study that directly investigates social cognition (reasoning about others’ mental states) in a sample of healthy adults (n=45, ages 19–23). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (social > mechanical, mechanical > social, task > rest) with random-effects analyses and provides peak coordinates (Appendix A) and statistical maps/figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The healthy/control group results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults; analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only methods. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-only, participants are within age range). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of empathy/perspective-taking (social cognition) in healthy adults (n=18, ages 21–31). It reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (Self vs Other, View-Pain vs View-No-Pain) with FWE-corrected results and tables of MNI coordinates, conjunction and regression analyses—meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task is clearly social (perspective taking/empathy). Participants are healthy adults within the 17–65 range. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports healthy-group effects generalizable to adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (final N=27, mean age ~27), addressing affiliative/attachment-related social processing. It used a task with affiliative vs nonaffiliative social scenarios and modeled condition-specific events with a canonical HRF. Group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses are reported (FWE-corrected results and whole-brain contrasts such as affiliative vs nonaffiliative and valence contrasts), not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. The reported maps and coordinates are clearly from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (task-based fMRI, healthy adult sample within range, and group-level whole-brain univariate results).

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI probing social-related processing (naturalistic audiovisual clips targeting eight social features such as faces, social interaction, emotion, speech). (2) Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=19; ages 21–34). (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task analyses (first- and second-level GLM, one-sample t-tests across subjects) with voxelwise statistics (FDR-corrected p<0.05), figures and coordinate tables. (4) Not limited to ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore this study should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis of healthy adult fMRI social processing.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (observation of cooperative vs affective social interactions) in healthy adults (n=27; ages within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (random-effects, FWE-corrected and uncorrected maps, conjunctions, direct contrasts) with coordinates and figures, not limited to ROI-only results. It is not a connectivity-only, resting-state, patient-only, or non-empirical paper. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=17 males, mean age 23.6) that used task-based functional MRI while presenting social stimuli (affiliation/romantic-love and power-related film clips). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (affiliation > control; power > control) and regression analyses linking motive scores to BOLD responses, with activation clusters reported as MNI coordinates and significance thresholds. The sample falls within the target adult age range (17–65). Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only methods. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=36) that investigates social cognition (simulation/prediction of others’ decisions). The experiment used task-based fMRI with whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses reporting voxelwise activations (tables of coordinates and thresholded maps; corrected p-values reported) for variables related to others’ reward/action prediction errors and decision variables (e.g., vmPFC, dmPFC/dlPFC, TPJ). Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. The paper provides full methods, behavioral modeling, and whole-brain statistical maps/tables, meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, not a review). Therefore it should be included.

Meets all inclusion criteria: The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=94 healthy females, ages 18–35) using a social-affective task (Socio-affective Video Task) probing empathy/compassion (perception/understanding of others). Group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts and parametric modulation results are reported (e.g., HE vs LE videos; activations in anterior insula, aMCC, mOFC, putamen, VTA/SN) with whole-brain FWE-corrected statistics and tables/figures. Results for the healthy sample are presented and generalizable within the healthy adult population studied. The study is empirical original fMRI research (longitudinal training design) and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Therefore it qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants watching emotional movies (naturalistic social-emotional stimulation) and examines neural synchrony underlying social/emotional processing. The paper reports voxelwise, whole-brain intersubject correlation (ISC) analyses and links moment-to-moment valence/arousal ratings to ISC, with group-level maps/localizations (sensory, corticolimbic, default-mode, attention networks) reported across the brain. This meets inclusion requirements: (1) social-related processing (empathy/emotional contagion/understanding others), (2) healthy adult sample, and (3) group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (reported as ISC maps and region lists). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy-group maps are provided). Therefore include.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (empathy/self–other overlap, familiarity) using healthy adult participants (n=22; mean age 23.6 within 17–65). The methods report whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (threat minus safe) with conjunction analyses and whole-brain corrected analyses, cluster thresholds, and reported coordinates/figures/tables of group-level univariate activation maps. Results include group-level whole-brain contrasts and supplementary whole-brain analyses; analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of affective speech comprehension (social communication / perception of others) in healthy adults (n=51, ages 18–53). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (EMO vs GRAM) with FWE-corrected maps and coordinate tables, and describes event-related whole-brain analyses and activation maps. Results for the healthy sample are reported directly and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, resting-state, or connectivity-only analyses, and does not report only between-group contrasts or clinical samples. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (impression formation/updating) in healthy adult participants (N=24, ages 18–45). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (e.g., interaction of trial number and evaluative consistency; L2>F3 contrasts for inconsistent targets) with thresholding and cluster results presented in tables and figures. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses; whole-brain voxelwise maps and coordinates are reported and described. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related (self- vs other-referential processing of valenced adjectives), directly relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Self/Other’. (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants aged 18–52 (N=20 women), within 17–65. (3) The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (voxelwise GLM results and contrasts: S-N, S-P, O-N, O-P vs fixation and planned contrasts; whole-brain maps reported with voxel-wise thresholds and cluster tables/figures). (4) Not ROI-only: although ROI/SVC analyses are included, whole-brain results are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria are violated (not resting-state/seed-only, not only between-group contrasts, empirical fMRI data in healthy adults). Therefore include.

This is an fMRI study of empathic decision-making (a social cognition task: empathic choice) in healthy adult participants (n=32, mean age 22.8, right-handed, no neurological/metabolic illness), which falls within the 17–65 age range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (multiple GLMs with cluster-level whole-brain correction reported; Tables and figures provide coordinates and contrasts), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although vmPFC results use small-volume correction for a strong a priori hypothesis, the manuscript also presents whole-brain cluster-corrected activations (e.g., IPL, precuneus, middle frontal gyrus) and corresponding tables/figures. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/only connectivity, and is empirical). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition (social working memory) in healthy adults (n=16, mean age 20). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (parametric load regressors) with voxelwise results and coordinate tables/figures, random-effects group inference, and thresholding procedures. The task explicitly probes social constructs (perspective-taking, mentalizing). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adult behavioral and neural results generalizable to the healthy group, and falls within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (in-group vs out-group action perception/affiliation) in healthy adult participants (ages 17–43). Group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses are reported (e.g., single-video vs fixation, own-team vs other-team, paired-judgment vs press) using random-effects SPM5; results are thresholded with cluster-level FWE correction for the whole-brain search and coordinates/clusters are reported. Sample meets age and health criteria and healthy-group results are clearly described. The paper does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and is not a review or methods-only paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of emotional prosody comprehension, a social-related task probing perception and understanding of others’ emotions (including complex social emotions requiring theory-of-mind). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=19 after exclusion), ages 18–51, within the 17–65 range. Whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses are reported (SPM8 one-sample t-tests and contrasts: emotional>neutral; complex>simple; analyses controlled for pitch), with cluster-level correction and reported activation maps/tables. The study is empirical and reports healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain results, not ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of biological motion perception (perception/understanding of others), a social-related process. Participants are healthy adults (13 right-handed males, mean age 28.2 years), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate task contrasts (canonical vs. scrambled biological motion) with cluster results corrected for multiple comparisons and tables of MNI coordinates (Table 1 and figures). Although connectivity/DCM analyses are included, the study also provides the required whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy control group, satisfying all inclusion criteria.

While the study used fMRI in a social task (ultimatum game) with healthy adult participants and reports whole-brain multivariate classification results (discriminative voxels from SVM weights), it does not provide a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (e.g., GLM contrast or main-effect voxelwise activation) for the healthy group. Reported results focus on ROI analyses and multivariate classification-derived discriminative volumes (permutation-based SVM weight maps), which do not fulfill the review's requirement for an univariate, group-level whole-brain activation map generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (social exclusion using the Cyberball task) in healthy adults (final sample n=20, mean age ~25, within 17–65). The paper reports univariate, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., social exclusion > fair play; same-gender vs other-gender exclusion) with cluster correction, tables of activation (coordinates) and figures, and random-effects group analyses generalizable to healthy adults. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain voxelwise results are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a review, and participants are within the required age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (n=14, mean age 35.9) that explicitly manipulates social interaction (human–human vs human–machine competition; Theory-of-Mind context). The authors report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses (SPM5) and provide univariate task-evoked contrasts (main effects and interaction contrasts) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster information (Tables 2–4) and figures. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range, healthy participants are reported separately, and results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of audiovisual emotion perception (social communication) in healthy adults (n=24, ages 18–34). The experiment uses task-evoked designs and reports random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM contrasts, conjunctions) with thresholded maps and coordinate tables, comparing congruent/incongruent audiovisual and unimodal conditions. Results are presented for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or non-empirical methods. Age range and reporting meet inclusion criteria, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly described. Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=19, ages 19–28) that directly investigates social-related processing (stereotypes/social-category knowledge). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate contrasts (e.g., social>non-social and non-social>social) with corrected thresholds, peak coordinates, tables and figures—i.e., voxelwise task-evoked activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes no clinical-only group. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study is an fMRI task of social cognition in healthy adult participants (mean age 18.7) and reports group-level contrasts. However, all primary inferential analyses were region-of-interest (ROI)-restricted: group SPM{t} maps were corrected for multiple comparisons within a priori ROIs and key results are reported from these ROIs (with some exploratory ROI analyses). The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain voxelwise group-level task activation map generalizable to the healthy adult population. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level whole-brain univariate task map (voxelwise), this study must be excluded despite meeting other criteria (task domain and healthy adult sample).

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (eye contact and spontaneous mimicry) in healthy adult participants (N=20, mean age 23).
