The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Congruent > Catch, Incongruent > Congruent, Direct > Averted, interaction contrasts) with cluster-level FWE correction and tables of coordinates (Table 1) and figures, all from the healthy/control group. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results, includes random-effects group analysis, and participants are within the 17–65 age range. No exclusion criteria are met, so the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI of observing virtual social interactions, addressing social processing. Participants (group-level results from N=15) are described as typical recruited subjects with informed consent, implying healthy adults. The paper presents group-level, univariate whole-brain activation maps/contrast results (t-value activation maps and time courses) showing activity in social cognition regions (STS, mPFC, amygdala), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of prosocial decisions (social processing: family-related affiliation/attachment) in a sample of healthy young adults (N=25, mean age 20.2). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (Costly-Donation vs Noncostly-Reward) with tables of coordinates, thresholding and correction procedures described, and whole-brain regression and PPI analyses. Results for the healthy adult group are reported and generalizable; the study is not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Age and sample meet the 17–65 criterion and healthy-group effects are clearly presented. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI using dynamic social interaction videos in a sample of 20 healthy young adults (within adult age range). The abstract and article metadata explicitly state whole-brain and hemispheric activation results, reporting group-level effects (right > left activation) in multiple brain regions (amygdaloid complex, inferior frontal gyrus, fusiform gyrus, temporal gyri) for social interaction conditions. This indicates univariate, group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical effects from the healthy adult group rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Although the full article PDF is paywalled, the abstract provides clear evidence that all inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and reported whole-brain group results). Minor uncertainty remains because full tables/figures are behind a paywall, hence confidence <1.0.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (representation of social interaction, social context vs solitary, self-generation) in healthy adult participants (N=24, mean age 20.5). It reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects SPM results) with coordinates/tables and thresholding, identifying mPFC and other regions for social context and self-generation. The sample is within the 17–65 age range, and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (race-based impression formation) using a task-evoked impression-formation paradigm assessing perception/understanding of others. Sample comprises healthy adult participants (Caucasian Americans aged 19–34; N=44 after exclusions), meeting the age and health criteria. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts and tables of peak coordinates (see Table 2 and Table 3) and describes whole-brain exploratory regression results (thresholds, cluster-correction via AlphaSim), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study also includes ROI analyses but crucially provides univariate, group-level whole-brain activation maps/contrasts for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of humor processing—a social-cognition phenomenon (perception/understanding of others/social communication). Sample: 29 healthy right-handed adults (mean age 27, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise analyses (SPM5) including contrasts (Cartoons vs Neutral) and parametric modulation (funniness ratings), with tables of peak coordinates, conjunctions, and corrected inference (FWE and Monte Carlo cluster correction). Results for the healthy group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 29.4, within 17–65) using a social-related task (categorization of point-light displays as social interaction vs non-social). The analysis reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects univariate contrasts (SI > NSI) with FDR-corrected results and cluster reporting; activations are described in text/tables/figures. The design and reported results are not ROI-only, not solely connectivity or resting-state, and not limited to between-group contrasts. Thus it satisfies all inclusion criteria (task fMRI of social processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level task-evoked maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=98 across four experiments; mean age 20.7) that uses task-based paradigms probing social processes (self/close others/strangers; perception and understanding of self and others, affiliation/closeness). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., self > Bush, friends > strangers) and presents whole-brain maps and region-level analyses; whole-brain results are explicitly described and thresholded (p<0.001 uncorrected). Results for the healthy adult sample are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task-based social fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain univariate group maps) and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social gaze affecting action control—social communication/perception of others). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=23, ages 21–37) with results reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (SPM second-level ANOVA), with suprathreshold clusters, coordinate tables and figures (cluster-level corrected maps). It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a non-empirical paper. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore include.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing/inferring others’ preferences) in healthy adults (n=64; age range 18–26). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses linking BOLD response to self–other discrepancy, including peak coordinates and a table of significant clusters (MPFC, orbitofrontal cortex, IFG, thalamus). Results are reported for the healthy/control participants and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (reported as coordinates/tables and figures). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study used task-based fMRI during an explicitly social communication task (charades/gestural communication) in healthy adult participants (final N=18; mean age 27.5). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses: a traditional GLM was used to identify mirror-system ROIs (seed regions defined from group GLM contrasts), and whole-brain differential Granger-causality (bbGCM) maps are presented and thresholded at the group level. Results and statistical maps are described for the healthy adult sample and are generalizable to healthy adults (ages within 17–65). Although connectivity analyses are a primary focus, univariate whole-brain GLM results (used to define seed ROIs and discussed relative to bbGCM) are reported/used, so the study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only reporting. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=24, ages 19–31) that investigates recognition of personally familiar versus famous and unfamiliar faces—a social cognition task involving perception/understanding of others and affiliation/attachment components. The study reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (SPM5 random-effects second-level one-sample t tests) with results presented as tables and brain maps. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes within-group healthy adult contrasts generalizable to healthy populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social preference task) in healthy adults (N=21, ages 23–51). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Preference vs. Gender and task vs. baseline) with voxelwise statistical maps and tables of activation peaks (FDR-corrected, whole-brain threshold, coordinates provided). Although the study also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it explicitly provides healthy-group whole-brain task activation results. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range, and the report contains original empirical fMRI data. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study of empathy and intimacy (social-affiliation/attachment) in healthy adult participants (N=36, mean age 23). It uses task-based fMRI with perspective-taking stimuli (Self, Loved-one, Stranger) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (Pain > Neutral and direct contrasts) with voxelwise statistics (FDR-corrected thresholds) and tables of MNI coordinates. Healthy-group results are reported and generalizable to adults 17–65. The paper also includes connectivity analyses but not exclusively; whole-brain task activation maps are clearly provided. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (Experiment 1: n=16, age 18–29; Experiment 2: n=13, age 18–29) using social-related tasks (live face-to-face interaction and joint attention). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Live > Recorded; Joint Attention > Solo Attention) with voxelwise results presented in tables (MNI coordinates) and thresholded whole-brain maps, corrected for multiple comparisons. Results for the healthy/control participants are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of charitable donation decisions (a social cognition task involving empathy/perspective-taking). Sample: healthy adults (N=22 females, ages 19–38), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses and corrected results (e.g., VMPFC correlated with donation value; pSTC correlated with willingness-to-give), with whole-brain correction and coordinates/figures/tables. It also reports contrasts (free vs forced) and between-subjects regressions, all conducted and described for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only, not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain fMRI of social-related processing.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (joint attention/representation of what another sees) in healthy adults (N=12 analyzed; ages 20–31). It reports group-level, univariate whole-brain random-effects contrasts (body > place and place > body) with tables of coordinates and thresholding details, not limited to ROI analyses. The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others). All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult within 17–65).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self- and other-referential trait judgments and memory) in healthy adults (n=13, ages 19.4–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (SPM contrasts such as self>syllables, old/same>new), including tables of peak coordinates and voxelwise statistical maps described in the text. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy control group are reported. The study is empirical and not ROI-only, not limited to connectivity/resting-state, and provides whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports original task-based fMRI data in healthy adult participants (n=16; mean age 27.8) using social/empathy stimuli. It includes group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects GLM; ANOVA contrasts such as emotional vs. neutral and two vs. one person) with coordinates and statistical maps (FDR q<0.05) reported. The task probes perception and understanding of others (social cognition/empathy), matching the review constructs. No exclusion criteria apply: results are not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) using a naturalistic MASC task in healthy adult participants (n=18; age range 20–45). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM contrasts (e.g., ToM > PI) with voxelwise thresholding and cluster correction, provides tables of coordinates and figures of activation maps, and clearly presents results for the healthy/control group. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-connectivity only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/perception of others’ pain and perceived agency) in healthy adults (n=26, mean age 24.4). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., pain > no-pain; social context effects; interaction), with tables of stereotactic coordinates and FDR-corrected thresholds, and figures illustrating whole-brain activations. Although ROI and PPI connectivity analyses are included, whole-brain univariate results for the healthy control sample are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (integration of non-verbal vocalizations and facial movements — social communication/perception of others) in healthy adults (fMRI sample: 10 right-handed males, ages 24–37). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate fMRI analyses (voxel-by-voxel t tests, percent signal change maps, corrected with AlphaSim) with group activation maps and difference maps (AV, VIS, AUD vs rest and contrasts), presented in figures/tables. Whole-brain voxelwise results are clearly reported for the healthy group (even though slice coverage emphasized temporal cortex), and healthy adult results are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social/attachment-related processing in a sample of 51 healthy adults (mean age 28.5), within the 17–65 range. The task used facial emotional (sad/happy/neutral) stimuli relevant to affiliation/attachment. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (masked sad > neutral; masked happy > neutral) with tables of coordinates and cluster statistics and voxelwise regression analyses relating attachment avoidance to activation; results are presented for a priori ROIs and whole-brain (FDR-corrected) regions. The healthy-group whole-brain univariate activation maps are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI-only results, non-healthy sample, resting-state-only) are violated.

This is an event-related fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (n=18 analyzed, age 18–22) using a social Trust Game—a social cognition task probing reciprocity/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., defect>reciprocate) with MNI coordinates, significance thresholds, cluster correction (AlphaSim) and tables/figures of whole-brain results. Analyses are random-effects/group-level and results are clearly reported for the healthy control sample. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition using the Reading the Mind in the Eyes task (mental state decoding), a social-related construct (perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (14 right-handed white American and 14 right-handed native Japanese adults aged 18–27). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (RME - gender baseline and same- vs other-culture contrasts) with tables of activated regions and coordinates (including family-wise corrected results), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports healthy-group results separately. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=43, age range mean 26.7 within 17–65). The task probes social-related processing (empathy, perception/understanding of others’ pain and self–other distinction). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain mass-univariate analyses (contrasts: genuine pain – no pain; pretended pain – no pain; interaction) with cluster-level FWE correction and activation maps/coordinates across whole brain (bilateral aIns, aMCC, rSMG), and also presents brain–behavior regression results. Thus it provides univariate task-evoked whole-brain results for a healthy adult sample. It does not rely solely on ROI-only or connectivity-only findings. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others via dynamic pupillary signals). Sample consists of healthy adults (N=14, mean age 22), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (main effect of viewing eye stimuli reported at a whole-brain corrected cluster threshold p<.05; effects of pupil-size change reported with voxelwise thresholds and cluster reports, with coordinates and Z/t values). The study is empirical, task-based, not limited to ROI-only analyses or connectivity-only approaches, and reports results generalizable to a healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12, ages 22–37) that used a social-related auditory task (listening to one vs two people walking) tapping social perception/mentalizing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate GLM analyses with voxelwise contrasts (e.g., STEP1+STEP2 – REST, STEP1 – NOISE1, STEP2 – NOISE2), statistical thresholds (p<.001 and p<.005 uncorrected), Talairach normalization, tables of coordinates, and figures showing whole-brain activation maps. Results for the healthy adult group are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, not only between-group contrasts, empirical data present). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI experiment probing social-related processing (observation of social vs individual actions; role of gaze) in healthy adult participants (N=17, mean age 26, right-handed, no neurological history). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (within-subjects ANOVA), with voxelwise statistical maps (SPM{t} maps) and coordinates/tables (p<.001 uncorrected, extent threshold reported) for main effects and interaction. Results are presented for the healthy/control sample and are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Age range and sample meet inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (face target detection) in a healthy adult sample (N=19; ages 19.3–47.5). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (face targets vs. novels, shape targets vs. novels, and their direct comparison) with cluster-corrected thresholds and MNI coordinates (Table 2), clearly coming from the healthy/control group. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only; participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of gaze-related social processing in healthy adults (behavioral n=10; fMRI n=12; ages 18–40). The task probes social communication/attention (social vs unsocial faces, correct vs incorrect gaze shifts). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses were performed using SPM2 and reported (main effects and multiple contrasts, with coordinates/tables and figures), i.e. univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports within-group random-effects results for healthy participants. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adult participants (N=18, mean age 20) performing social-related tasks (age categorization and vegetable-preference mentalizing). The paper reports whole-brain, random-effects GLM analyses with voxelwise contrasts, cluster sizes, and Talairach coordinates for group-level task effects (task main effects and group-member contrasts). Results are presented as whole-brain maps/tables rather than ROI-only analyses. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (approaching characters showing happy vs. angry expressions), conducted in healthy adult participants (10 right-handed young adults). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain random-effects contrasts (Angry>Happy and Happy>Angry) with MNI coordinates and cluster descriptions (Table 1 and figures). The task probes social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others, affiliation/dominance). No evidence that results are limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses; whole-brain univariate activation maps are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and healthy-group results are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of socially relevant facial expressions/mimicry). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=17, right-handed males, mean age 25.9) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate (voxelwise) analyses using an FIR model with random-effects inference and reports significant activations (thresholds, coordinates, SPM maps/tables) for the main effect of social interaction (time-bin 5). Results are clearly reported for the healthy control group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (theory of mind/social-exchange reasoning) in healthy adults. The sample includes healthy adult participants (final N=12, mean age 24.6, within the 17–65 range). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level, univariate task-evoked analyses (GLM, random-effects) with voxelwise contrasts (story and card contrasts) and lists brain areas/clusters (tables of activations and coordinates) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI task study in healthy adults (n=12 analyzed; ages 21–31) investigating social cognition (attribution of intentions/perception and understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (Composer > Computer) with voxelwise results and a table of peak coordinates and corrected cluster statistics, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task explicitly probes social-related processing (mental state attribution) rather than only ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only; participants within 17–65; healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=17, age range 20–34) that investigates social communication cues (gaze following and finger pointing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (gaze following vs baseline; finger pointing vs baseline; subtraction contrasts) with random-effects group analysis and cluster-level inference; coordinates and activation maps are provided. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately and are generalizable to the healthy adult population. The study is empirical, uses task fMRI (not solely ROI or connectivity), and meets all inclusion criteria while violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (social motor response learning) in healthy adults (n=18; mean age 42 ±12, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (one-group t-tests) with results thresholded and reported using whole-brain FDR correction (P<0.05) and tables of coordinates and figures (Tables II–III, Figures 3–4). The healthy control group results are reported directly and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity/resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: fMRI during social-related/empathy task (SELF vs OTHER perspective-taking using emotional faces), clearly social cognition. (2) Sample: 26 healthy right-handed adults (12 males, 14 females), mean ages ~24 (within 17–65). (3) Whole-brain evidence: group-level, voxelwise univariate contrasts (SELF vs baseline, OTHER vs baseline) reported with whole-brain FWE-corrected maps and tables of MNI coordinates; gender comparisons also reported but primary healthy-group simple effects are provided. (4) Not ROI-only or connectivity-only: whole-brain analyses and coordinate tables are present. Results are clearly reported for the healthy control group and generalizable. No exclusion criteria violated. Therefore include.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=35, ages 18–24) using a social-related task (self-, friend-, and unfamiliar-person recognition via face and name stimuli) addressing perception/understanding of self and others. The authors report group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses using SPM with random-effects one-sample t-tests and present tables of peak coordinates, cluster results, and whole-brain figures for multiple contrasts (self vs friend, friend vs self, familiarity effects). The paper is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and results for the healthy control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social interactive task (iterated Prisoner's Dilemma) comparing social vs non-social (Gamble) tasks. Participants are healthy adults (Experiment 1: 20 females, mean age ~20.8; Experiment 2: 30 adults, mean age ~21.2), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects univariate contrasts (PD > Gamble and in-group vs out-group), with tables of activation coordinates (e.g., Table 2) and thresholding details, and further whole-brain exploratory analyses and connectivity/Granger causality. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, empirical data present). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (72 recruited; 48 analyzed in social paradigms; ages 19–43/19–38 reported), using a social interaction task probing social hierarchy (relevant social construct: perception/understanding of others/status). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., “superior > inferior,” outcome contrasts) with voxelwise statistical maps and tables of peak coordinates (FDR-corrected thresholds) generalizable to healthy adults. Results are not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social cognition: cooperation/deception) in healthy adults (n=13, ages 22–38). The authors report group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (ToM conditions vs. non-ToM baseline) with cluster peaks/coordinates and figures, and they transformed maxima into Talairach space. Results are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts; healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication (viewing, imitating, and producing facial expressions and social hand gestures). The article reports group-level task-evoked activation localized to mirror neuron system regions (inferior parietal lobule, frontal operculum) and contrasts between conditions, indicating whole-brain univariate results rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. The sample is described as participants (healthy adults implied) and the task is directly social-processing relevant. The provided excerpt does not state explicit ages, so confidence is slightly reduced, but all other inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy-group whole-brain activation maps, empirical data) appear to be met.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=16, ages 18–29). The task investigates evaluating others’ actions vs intentions (social-related processing). The paper reports group-level, univariate voxelwise whole-brain analyses (voxelwise ANOVAs with reported thresholds and coordinates and voxelwise results described in text/figures), not only ROI results. Healthy adult sample results are reported and generalizable via random-effects analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated (not connectivity-only, not ROI-only, participants within age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This fMRI study investigates processing of emotional facial expressions (social communication) using explicit and implicit emotional paradigms in 12 healthy adult subjects. The abstract reports group-level task-evoked BOLD signal increases across multiple brain regions (thalami, hippocampi, frontal gyri, caudate, cingulum, right prefrontal cortex, occipital regions, cerebellum, etc.), indicating whole-brain univariate activation maps/contrasts for the healthy group rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants are healthy adults within the eligible age range. There is no indication the paper is non-empirical or limited to clinical groups only. Although the full PDF is paywalled, the reported group-level whole-brain activations meet the inclusion criteria for healthy adult task fMRI of social-related processing. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social interaction (approach/avoidance toward peers, including ‘friends’) in healthy adults (N=28, right-handed, mean age 22.6, range 19–27). The task targets social-related constructs (affiliation/attachment, perception of others). The authors report group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses (ANOVA/contrasts) with familywise-error correction and provide peak coordinates, cluster-corrected results, figures and tables of whole-brain activations. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, and reports healthy-group task effects generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication in healthy adults (N=29, ages 18–24). The task is explicitly social (communicative speech vs description) and examines social cognition. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses and provides coordinates and cluster sizes for contrasts (e.g., communication vs description, communication vs control) in tables and figures, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results are presented for the healthy/control group. The study is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a review. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking) in healthy adults using a task that manipulates self vs other judgments and perspective taking. The paper reports group-level task-evoked activations in medial prefrontal cortex subregions (ventral/dorsal anterior MPFC, posterior dorsal MPFC, left dorsal MPFC), indicating whole-brain univariate activation contrasts rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Participants are healthy adults (typical adult trait-adjective judgments), and results are reported as group effects generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not patient-only, and not non-empirical). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=26, mean age 29.4) that explicitly tests social-related processing (judgments of social concepts vs animal function concepts). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (categorical contrasts and conjunction analyses) with tables of MNI coordinates and whole-brain/statistical thresholding described; results for healthy participants are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Psycholinguistic variables and covariates are controlled and ROI analyses supplement but do not replace whole-brain reporting. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition: participants (healthy adult undergraduates, mean age 19.5) made affective/social judgments of pictures of social groups (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (random-effects contrasts, Talairach coordinates, and voxelwise activations for mPFC, insula, amygdala), not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Healthy adult sample falls within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social interaction (competitive reaction-time paradigm provoking reactive aggression) in healthy adult participants (N=16 males; mean age 28.6). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses with voxelwise statistics and provides tables of activation coordinates and figures for main effects and parametric modulations (retaliation, watching opponent, receiving aversive stimuli). Results for the healthy sample are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults examining perception of faces (neutral and fearful)—a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level brain responses (FFA, STS, amygdala) to visible and invisible faces, indicating task-evoked activations rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. Results are described at the group level and are generalizable to healthy adults. No indication that participants were outside the 17–65 range or that only clinical groups were studied. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria: social-related fMRI task in healthy adults with reported whole-brain task-evoked activations.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults (N=11, ages 18–32). The task probes perception and understanding of others (spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge/trait inferences). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results with voxelwise contrasts and lists significant clusters with Talairach coordinates and statistics (Tables 2 and 3; whole-brain contrasts such as faces associated with behaviors vs. novel faces; disgusting vs. aggressive). Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity methods, and the healthy adult group results are reported and generalizable to the target population (age within 17–65). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range sample) are violated. Note: sample size is small but does not violate inclusion criteria as healthy-group whole-brain results are provided.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=16 recruited, 15 analyzed; ages 20–28) investigating perception/recognition of self-generated vs external visual feedback (ownership/agency), a construct falling under ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise SPM analyses and provides thresholded whole-brain statistical maps and tables of peak coordinates for contrasts (Aa-As, Pa-Ps). It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state, and the healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=18, mean age 25.9) examining social communication/self-involvement using virtual characters. It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., SOC>ARB, ARB>SOC, ME>OTHER, OTHER>ME, interactions) with stereotactic coordinates, thresholds, and figures/tables—fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task is clearly social-related (gaze, social/arb facial expressions). Analyses use standard SPM random-effects inference and results are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor limited to clinical participants, so it meets all inclusion and no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=13; right-handed males, age range 19–36) using a social-cognition task (nonverbal cartoons probing Theory of Mind and empathy). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., ‘ToM’–‘Physical 1’, ‘Empathy’–‘Physical 2’), a conjunction analysis, and interaction contrasts, with tables of activation coordinates and thresholding (z>3.09, P<0.001 uncorrected). Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study meets all inclusion criteria (fMRI task probing social processes, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and whole-brain univariate group maps presented). No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a non-empirical paper, and healthy-group effects are reported).

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=15, mean age 24.4) that investigates processing of anger prosody — a social-communication/emotion perception task relevant to social cognition. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses and provides voxelwise results (statistical parametric maps described in text and a table of MNI coordinates/clusters), including contrasts of anger vs. neutral and attention-by-emotion interactions. Analyses were whole-brain (SPM2 RFX) and results are generalizable to healthy adults; no ROI-only or connectivity-only restriction applies. Participants fall inside the 17–65 range and healthy-group results are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a 3T BOLD fMRI study of self-face recognition (a social-cognitive task: Perception/Understanding of Self) in healthy adults. Sample: 12 healthy right-handed male undergraduates (mean age ~19), within the 17–65 range; results for the healthy group are reported separately. Analysis: group-level, random-effects, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate contrasts (e.g., self vs. familiar, familiar vs. unknown) analyzed in SPM2; whole-brain statistical maps and tables of coordinates are reported and figures displayed. The study thus provides whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked activation maps relevant to the review objective. Although sample is small and limited to males (not exclusionary), all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=14; ages 18.3–23.7) that targets social-cognitive processing (impression formation about people vs. objects). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (e.g., person-impression > others; impression > sequencing) with voxel-based thresholding (P<0.001), regions-of-interest and stereotaxic coordinates in tables and figures. Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable within the adult range 17–65. The study does not rely solely on ROIs, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study (two separate fMRI experiments) investigating theory-of-mind/understanding intentions — a social cognition task relevant to the review. The paper appears to report group-level task-evoked activations identifying the anterior paracingulate cortex, consistent with whole-brain, univariate contrasts typical for J Cogn Neurosci fMRI reports. Participants are implied to be healthy adults (no clinical groups are indicated in the abstract or metadata). Therefore it meets: fMRI during social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain univariate task activation reporting. Confidence is slightly reduced because participant ages are not explicitly listed in the provided excerpt, but overall evidence supports inclusion.

The study reports task-based fMRI of social-related evaluative processes (guilt and embarrassment), using a sample of 19 healthy adults (ages within 17–65). Group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate contrasts (guilt minus neutral; embarrassment minus neutral; direct contrasts) are reported with thresholded maps, tables of peak coordinates, and figures. It is not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and healthy-group activation maps are clearly presented and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (12 right-handed participants, ages 21–28) that manipulates social interaction (cooperation, competition, independent play). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., cooperation vs independent, competition vs independent, cooperation vs competition) with tables of activation coordinates and statistical thresholds (voxel-level P<0.001; tables 1 and 2). Results are clearly reported for the healthy participant group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and does not focus on a clinical/subgroup without separate healthy-group results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study is an fMRI investigation of social gaze in healthy adult participants and uses voxelwise analyses; however, the reported group-level whole-brain activation maps were created by averaging normalized data across subjects using a fixed-effects analysis. Fixed-effects group maps are not generalizable to the healthy adult population (they only reflect the sampled subjects) and therefore do not meet the inclusion requirement for a group-level, population-generalizable whole-brain task-evoked statistical map. Additionally, after discarding 3 subjects for motion, the effective fMRI sample was very small (n≈5), further limiting population inference. Although the task and sample are appropriate, the use of fixed-effects group analysis (and the small final N) violates the requirement that whole-brain results be generalizable to healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=13; mean age 27.2), using video clips of social interactions (social relational processing). Group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses are reported (ANOVA, voxelwise threshold P≤0.05 corrected; tables of coordinates and figures provided), showing activations for relational vs. alone and relational vs. rest. The healthy control group results are explicitly presented and generalizable to healthy adults within the 17–65 range. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and does not present only between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (scanned N=11, mean age 25.6) using a social interactive task (sequential Prisoner’s Dilemma) addressing social cognition (moral status, cooperation/defection). Group-level, random-effects voxelwise analyses are reported (SPM2), with whole-brain contrasts and tables of peak coordinates (Tables 2 and 3) and figures showing task-evoked activations (e.g., cooperator vs neutral, defector vs neutral, intentional vs nonintentional). Results are generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to an ROI-only or connectivity-only analysis. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social evaluation (trustworthiness of faces) in healthy adults (14 analyzed participants, ages 18–30). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, univariate whole-brain analyses (SPM one-sample t-tests across subjects) with reported voxelwise results and coordinates (including small-volume corrections and whole-brain activations described in text/tables/figures). The task is a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). It is empirical, not connectivity-only or ROI-only, and the healthy-group results are reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult volunteers (n=10) performing social cognition tasks (empathy and forgivability judgments), which map directly onto social-related processing. The paper explicitly reports group-level task activations (e.g., left superior frontal gyrus, orbitofrontal gyrus, precuneus, anterior temporal and inferior frontal gyri, posterior cingulate), indicating univariate, whole-brain task effects rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Participants are healthy adults within the eligible age range. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and provides healthy-group whole-brain results). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social-related face perception task in healthy adult participants, the full text/abstract emphasizes ROI-based analyses of amygdala voxels and does not clearly report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps for the healthy group. Inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain healthy-group task effect; exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting only ROI analyses. Therefore this study must be excluded for lacking clearly reported whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social interaction (SI) recognition using point-light displays — a social-related construct (Perception/Understanding of Others). The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (SI > NM) for each age group, including adults, using SPM8 with peak- and cluster-level thresholds and FWE correction; results are presented for the adult group (tables/figures described). It is not ROI-only, not solely connectivity or resting-state, and provides an unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task activation map generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in NeuroImage (2015) that tested healthy adults (N=30, mean age ~24) on implicit emotion/gender identification tasks using angry and happy faces versus neutral shapes — a social/emotional processing paradigm (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts: main effects of stimulus type were assessed via FWE-corrected whole-brain analyses and reported (see supplementary tables/figures), along with interaction and conjunction analyses; thus whole-brain, voxelwise healthy-group activation maps are available. The sample is within the 17–65 adult range and results are reported for the healthy group. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of face perception (Perception and Understanding of Others), a social-related process. Participants: 25 healthy adults (mean age 25.24), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrast (natural-colored face vs natural-scrambled) with peak coordinates, cluster sizes (Table 1) and figures, i.e., univariate whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain results are explicitly reported. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of active interpersonal touch (social-related processing) in a healthy adult sample (N=16, ages 20–34). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (contrast maps, interaction effects, conjunctions) with cluster-level correction and coordinates presented (Table 1 and figures). Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults (not restricted to a clinical subgroup). The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and not limited to connectivity/resting-state or between-group contrasts. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Contains a healthy adult group (n=19; ages 22–31) and reports task-based fMRI whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (ANOVA and group contrasts) with multiple-comparison correction. The study uses a social-related task (direct and reflected self-evaluations, social domain) and reports group-level whole-brain results and follow-up adult-only analyses (noted in the main text and Supplementary Materials, including tables/coordinates). Thus it meets the sample, task, and whole-brain univariate reporting criteria for inclusion.

Although the study used task fMRI in healthy adults (ages 22–39) and addressed social touch, it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (e.g., GLM contrast or voxelwise t-map). The analyses are based on ICA-derived components and component time courses (multivariate/component maps) rather than conventional whole-brain task activation contrasts. Per the review’s inclusion criteria, studies must provide at least one healthy-group whole-brain voxelwise task activation map; studies reporting only ICA/component or connectivity-focused results without accompanying univariate whole-brain task maps must be excluded.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (multiround Ultimatum Game). It includes a healthy adult group (n=15; ages 19–28) reported separately from child and adolescent groups. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses: one-sample t-tests per group and between-group full-factorial ANOVAs, and the primary contrast (unfair > fair offers) is presented with whole-brain statistical maps and coordinate tables (Table 1) thresholded at p<.001 uncorrected. Results for the healthy adult group are explicitly reported and generalizable to healthy adults (within the 17–65 range). The study is empirical and provides whole-brain task-evoked activation maps/coordinates for the healthy adult sample, so it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=20, ages 23–39) that probes social-related processing (judgments of social coordination vs relationship familiarity). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., rough > smooth, rough > none) with voxelwise statistics and FDR-corrected results and tables of peak coordinates. Analyses are not limited to ROIs, nor are they connectivity- or resting-state only. Healthy-group whole-brain activation maps are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

Although the study uses fMRI with social stimuli (face perception) and includes a healthy adult subgroup (ages 18–37), it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy adult group alone. The paper’s whole-brain voxelwise results are reported as age-regression analyses across a mixed-age sample (children, adolescents, adults). Adult data are reported for ROI/FFA measures and descriptive statistics, but no unmasked whole-brain healthy-adult task map/contrast is presented in the main text. Thus criterion requiring a group-level whole-brain task map for the healthy adult group is not met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses fMRI during a social-related task (passive viewing of point-light biological vs. scrambled motion probing social perception), includes a healthy adult sample reported separately (n=48, ages 20–35), and provides group-level, whole-brain voxelwise univariate contrasts (biological > scrambled) for the adult group with cluster-corrected thresholds, tables of coordinates, and figures. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related — perception/categorization of others (face gender), which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others.’ (2) Sample comprises healthy adults (N=16, ages 19–42; one excluded for motion; analyses reported on healthy participants). (3) The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects contrast gender-different > gender-same with reported clusters and thresholding), generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only; not connectivity- or between-group-only; participants are within 17–65). Therefore include.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (affiliation vs isolation) in healthy adults. It reports whole-brain, voxelwise, group-level univariate analyses (GLM, random-effects) with thresholded results and coordinate tables/figures for task contrasts (social vs nonsocial; affiliation vs isolation) and age-group contrasts. The sample includes a healthy younger adult group (mean age 20.75), which falls within the 17–65 inclusion range; results for healthy younger adults are analyzed and reported (e.g., conjunctions and Younger > Older contrasts), satisfying the requirement for a healthy adult group. The study is not ROI-only and does not report only connectivity or non-empirical data. Although an older group (>65) is included, that does not preclude inclusion because a qualifying healthy adult subgroup is present and reported separately.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=20, mean age 22) examining social-communication processing (responses to communicative vs noncommunicative vocal sounds). The task is clearly social-related (Social Communication/communicative intent). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (vocal > nonvocal and communicative > noncommunicative) with correction (FDR q<.05) and peak coordinates, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement for the healthy/control group. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy sample (no exclusive clinical sample). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes whole-brain healthy-group task maps). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of affective (social) touch including a healthy adult group (N=22, ages 19–35). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM analyses for adults (Arm>Rest, Palm>Rest) with cluster-corrected thresholds and tables/figures of activations (including pSTS, insula), satisfying whole-brain evidence. The task probes social/affiliative processing (affective-motivational touch) relevant to the review constructs. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adult subgroup within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of self-related social processing (self-face recognition) in healthy adults (N=16 analyzed for fMRI; ages 19–24). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Morph 50% recognized as self vs. friend) with thresholding and coordinates (MPFC, PCC, right precuneus reported at voxel/cluster-corrected thresholds). While ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain SPM results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, between-group-only contrasts, or non-empirical methods. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=9, mean age 24) investigating perception of eye gaze and identity—socially relevant processes (social communication; perception of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate activation contrasts (face > scrambled control; region coordinates and volumes provided in Table 1; statistical maps and figures shown), not ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Healthy-group results are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

Full text provided contains only the References section and bibliographic metadata; it lacks methods, participants, results, and statistical maps. I cannot confirm key inclusion criteria: (1) participant sample characteristics (whether a healthy adult group aged 17–65 was recruited and reported separately), and (2) presence of at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. The title suggests an fMRI face/gaze task (social processing), but this cannot substitute for explicit reporting required by the review. Because essential information to verify whole-brain results and healthy adult reporting is missing, the study must be excluded from the meta-analysis.

The supplied full-text content contains only the references and bibliographic metadata; no methods, participant details, task descriptions, or results are provided. Therefore it is impossible to confirm the presence of (1) a social-related fMRI task, (2) a healthy adult sample (age 17–65) reported separately if relevant, or (3) at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group. Because the inclusion criteria cannot be verified from the provided text, the study must be excluded.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (12 right-handed males, ages 20–51). The task probes social cognition (causal attributions, self- vs other-responsibility and self-serving bias), matching the review’s social-related constructs (perception/understanding of self and others). Analyses are whole-brain, voxelwise SPM99 contrasts (internal vs external attributions; self-serving vs non-self-serving), with tables of Talairach/MNI coordinates and corrected voxelwise statistics reported at the group level. Although primary inference used fixed-effects models (noted), whole-brain group-level univariate activation maps and coordinate tables are provided and additional random-effects ROI checks were reported. The paper is empirical, uses task-evoked whole-brain univariate analyses, and reports healthy-group results that are generalizable to the adult population within the review age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adults (n=10, mean age 26.9) investigating self-face recognition, which falls under social-related processing (perception/understanding of self). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (self > other and other > self) analyzed with FLAME and cluster-corrected thresholds, and provides tables of MNI coordinates and statistical maps/figures. It is original empirical fMRI data, not ROI-only or resting/connectivity-only, and the reported results are for the healthy adult group. Thus all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of facial emotion recognition (social communication/perception of others) in healthy adults (N=29, ages 20–35). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked analyses (random-effects; contrasts for explicit and implicit conditions) with tables of MNI coordinates and FWE-corrected results and figures showing whole-brain activation, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for the healthy control group are reported directly and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not limited to ROI-only analyses, and does not violate exclusion criteria. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of self vs. other body-part perception in healthy adult participants and directly addresses social/self perception. However, the primary experimental results are reported as ROI-based fMR‑adaptation analyses (3 mm3 EBA ROIs with percent signal change and ANOVAs). The paper uses whole-brain contrasts only to localize EBA/LOC/V1 (reporting peak coordinates and voxel counts), but it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the social/self contrasts (e.g., own/other vs other/other) that would be generalizable to the healthy adult group. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain task-evoked univariate map from the healthy group, and the study's main social-related comparisons are presented only as ROI-based effects, it fails the whole-brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This fMRI study tests action observation/execution (mirror system) in healthy adults (n=20, ages 20–34), addressing perception/understanding of others—a social-related construct in the review scope. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (conjunction analyses and peak coordinates) for the Compatible (control) group, thresholded at P<0.05 corrected across the whole brain, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses are not limited to ROIs, are task-based (not resting-state or connectivity-only), and include within-group activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of self-related social processing (perception/understanding of self), meeting the review’s topical scope. Sample: 24 healthy adult participants (native Japanese and Caucasian-American; ages ~21–24), within the 17–65 range and reported separately as groups. Analysis: authors report whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects task contrasts and multiple tables of coordinates (Tables II–V) and whole-brain regression results generalizable to healthy adults. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps for the healthy group are clearly provided. No exclusion criteria are violated.

While this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (explicit emotion recognition in 21 healthy young males) reporting group-level voxelwise analyses and ROI results, the imaging used a restricted slab optimized for the amygdala rather than whole-brain coverage. The paper explicitly notes restricted coverage and reports a “whole-slab” analysis (not whole-brain). The review’s inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map generalizable to healthy adults. Because the voxelwise analyses are limited to a restricted slab and do not constitute whole-brain results, the study fails the required whole-brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

While this is an fMRI study of social communication (audiovisual integration of non-verbal emotional signals) in healthy adults (n=24, ages 18–41), it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map. The analysis is an ROI-based approach using individually mapped STS measuring points; parameter estimates were extracted from spheres around those MPs and subjected to one-sample t-tests. Although MNI coordinates and T-values for STS MPs are reported and figures/probability maps are shown, the paper does not present an unmasked whole-brain voxelwise group contrast or map generalizable to the healthy adult population. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical map, and the exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting only ROI analyses, this study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of self-related social cognition (direct and reflected self-appraisals), involving a healthy adult sample (N=12, ages 22.6–30.4). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts and conjunction analyses for adults (e.g., direct and reflected appraisals vs. rest; reflected>direct), with coordinates and descriptions of whole-brain results. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state only, and healthy adult results are reported separately alongside adolescent data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (perception and production of emotional and linguistic prosody) in healthy adults (n=19, ages 18–58). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., “happy–neutral”, “question–neutral”) analyzed with random-effects models and thresholded at p<0.05 FDR (k>5), with results described in the text, figures, and supplementary materials (coordinate tables). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and the healthy adult sample falls within the 17–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (social expectancy violations along warmth and competence) in healthy adults (undergraduate sample, mean age 20.4, N=12 analyzed). The task is social (trait attributions about others). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects), with cluster coordinates, tables, figures, and corrected thresholds (reported Talairach coordinates and whole-brain contrasts). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy adult results are reported separately. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (emotion recognition and gaze integration) using an event-related task targeting social-cognitive constructs (mentalizing, emotion perception). It includes a healthy younger adult group (age 17–27), which meets the required 17–65 age range. The paper reports whole-brain analyses (partial least squares multivariate whole-brain analysis) and provides group-level results with peak coordinates, cluster tables, and figures reported separately for younger (healthy) and older groups, enabling extraction of healthy-group whole-brain activation patterns. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state, and not limited to between-group contrasts. Note: the analysis is multivariate PLS rather than a conventional univariate GLM, but whole-brain voxelwise saliences and coordinate tables are provided, so usable for coordinate-based inclusion. Therefore the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain task fMRI data.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=15, mean age 24.8) using an explicit task involving face individuation (perception/understanding of others), which falls under social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (voxelwise ANOVA and cluster-corrected maps/tables) for the healthy participant group and provides whole-brain contrasts and coordinates. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting analyses, and results for the healthy adult sample are reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study uses task fMRI of social processing and includes healthy adult participants (up to age 40); however, all whole-brain group-level activation maps and contrasts are reported for the combined sample spanning ages 7–40 or as age-correlations. The paper does not report a separate univariate, whole-brain group activation map or contrast specifically for a healthy adult subgroup (age 17–65). Thus it fails the requirement that healthy adult results be reported separately/generalizable to the healthy adult population.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (Cyberball social exclusion) in healthy participants and includes a distinct healthy adult group (ages ~23.9–38.8). The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (exclusion > inclusion) with cluster-level FWE-corrected results (Table 2) and voxel coordinates for significant clusters. It also reports a Condition × Age-group interaction and post-hoc within-adult t-tests (adult exclusion > inclusion; right vlPFC) with coordinates and statistics. Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Thus the study provides whole-brain, univariate task activation results from healthy adults and meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants using a social task (perception of others’ dynamic facial expressions), the reported neuroimaging results are derived primarily from region-of-interest (ROI) analyses with small-volume correction (WFU PickAtlas masks) and conjunctions within specified ROIs. The manuscript does not present or clearly describe an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map generalizable to the healthy group; reported effects appear restricted to ROI/SVC results. Therefore it fails the review’s requirement to report at least one whole-brain, group-level task-evoked statistical map, and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of reflective social processing in healthy adults (final N=17, mean age 21.5), using social-related tasks (self- and mother-referential processing and a Social Attribution Task/theory-of-mind animation). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and conjunctions (composite t-maps, FDR < .05 and uncorrected contrasts at p<.001), with peak coordinates and tables (Tables 2, 4, 5). Results are reported for the healthy/control sample separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI evidence of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=24; ages 22–39) that investigates social-related processing (collective memory, social knowledge, representation of group/narrative schemas). The task is a task-evoked recall task probing social/collective schema influences on memory (relevant constructs: perception/understanding of others, social knowledge). The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: a surface-based searchlight with second-level non-parametric random-effects analysis and TFCE correction (Pcorrected < 0.05) identifying clusters related to collective schema (Extended Data Fig.1), in addition to ROI results. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (healthy adult sample, social-related fMRI task, and group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) apply.

The study uses task-based fMRI during observation of social (interpersonal) touch, targeting social-affective processing. It includes a healthy neurotypical adult control group (N=21) reported separately. The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task effects (social vs. non-social touch) with mean group effects and peak coordinates presented in supplemental materials (Additional file 1: Figure S2 and Table S2), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The design is task-evoked (not resting-state or connectivity-only), and healthy-group results are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age outside 17–65, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of vocal versus non-vocal auditory processing—a paradigm clearly relevant to social communication/socially relevant stimulus processing. Participants are healthy adults within the target age range (Experiment 1: n=13, mean age 26.6; Experiment 2: n=18, mean age 23.1). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate activation maps and contrasts (vocal > non-vocal) with voxelwise thresholds (p<0.05 FDR), cluster thresholds, and MNI coordinates (Fig.1 and text). It is not ROI-only, nor limited to connectivity or resting-state results, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of action perception—clearly within ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ (social-related processing). It reports task-evoked, group-level voxelwise whole-brain analyses (e.g., ActionOBS–CtrlOBS and weight-discrimination contrasts) with thresholded statistical maps and localization, described for healthy adult participants across three experiments (total N=79) and separate analyses comparing healthy controls to SCA6 patients. Healthy adult results are reported independently of clinical groups. The paper therefore meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample in the 17–65 range, (3) whole-brain univariate group-level voxelwise maps, and (4) no exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes healthy-group whole-brain effects).

This is an fMRI study of social processing (trust, honesty, reputation, mentalizing) using task-based paradigms (take-advice game and trust game). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=31; mean age ~24), within 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (voxel-level p<0.001 and cluster-level FWE-corrected p<0.05) for contrasts such as honesty vs dishonesty and outcome-related activations, satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. It is empirical task fMRI (not ROI-only, not solely connectivity/resting-state), and results for the healthy group are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing and includes a healthy adult control group, the paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy/TD group. The reported activations are primarily ROI analyses and between-group contrasts; the whole-brain analyses described focus on group differences and report no significant additional activations. Because the review requires at least one clearly-identified whole-brain task-evoked map from the healthy/control group (or equivalent coordinate table/figure), this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.
